text: Dear Kamel Hatem, before you make such an unpleasant declaration about your 54 years of life, consider this. By the mere fact you have found it in your heart to make such a thoughtful, insightful and indeed endearing statement regarding the effects this young man's all too short life has had, tells me and doubtless many others, you are a person of some considerable substance. Indeed a person with such obvious substance, having the capacity and will to share their feelings, doubtless inspired by this outstanding, exemplary young man. People such as yourself who are so motivated, caring and insightful, bear absolutely no resemblance, or have any points in common with the person you describe, being yourself. Forgive me if I sound at all cliche, life and all it's problematic twists and turns, or sometimes prolonged periods of involuntary downtime should be judged by its overall quality and not by it's length. In conclusion, may I say your statement saddened me, try to focus on the positives you've created, your having undertaken to write your comment could not have been done by anyone who IS NOTHING,  rather it could only have been done by someone who IS SOMETHING. Most sincerely Jim D.

author: Inkypaint

text:
@Inkypaint I believe I know how you feel.  I too wrestle with certain possibilities and being a practical man coming to terms with my own experiences proved very difficult.  I can't nor would I try to convince you because you have to have your own experience.  Word alone is not enough, even if you did experience something you might think you're in need of medication.


I am not talking psychics or spiritual meetings, I can only tell you of my parent's experiences.  My father died in 1973 but six weeks before he told my mother his sister Amy came to him.  she sat down on the bed just before father left the bedroom and told him it was time for him to prepare for his passing.  She made two visits.  After my father passed away it was mid-1984 whilst my mother was watching television when she saw my father sat opposite her.


she thought she was losing her mind and left the room.  She returned with a cup of tea but father was still there.  This continued for the next eighteen months every two months or so, my mother passed away in 1986.  My sister received visitations from our mother apparently to let her know she was alright, I never received any such visits.


I cannot prove or disprove these claims, but when I was stationed in Germany I was on duty on my own when I had a number of experiences that were beyond explanation.  However, I ventured to mention to fellow troop members what had happened and was told, "why do you think duty was taken in the guardroom".  I have no explanation as to what happened, but suffice it say, it was not pleasant.  This probably proves nothing to you as it's just my word, but I know what I saw and I would not try to convince you one way or the other.  Justin.
author: Justin Case

text:
@Daniel Does the MS stand for multiple sclerosis?  That would be in-line with what I feel is your resentment.  You are obviously referring to the Old Testament, and we can all cherry-pick.  Since you appear to have read the Bible fully then you would know that Jesus was sent to spread the new word, a new covenant.  You missed the point of God's purpose which was to test the father's faith.  The story is a parable that explains that in many ways, life will test you, as were the parables spoke of by Jesus.


How accurate is the Bible (rhetorical)?  Word of mouth, misinterpretation or reinterpretation?  How many times has it been rewritten?  Adapted by different churches, for that matter how many variations are there?  For those who have and keep the faith find comfort, for those who don't, a boat without a rudder.  Remember this Daniel, when we get to the pearly gates St. Peter will ask us three questions, who are you, where do you come, from and do you have your membership card.

author: Hxtta

text: I guess you fools don't realize why people even say "they're better off dead", it's just like if people were on their death bed but we're holding on even though they're expected to be dead. It's because it's better off they AREN'T SUFFERING on this planet anymore. You people who say "I don't wanna see this person die!!" when they're unhealthy, sick, disabled, etc. are just making them suffer even more. By you saying "disabled" you're not telling us EXACTLY what he has, so you're basically saying "all disabled people should live as long as they should", which is not true, and is completely selfish to say. Sure you'll cry, but at least they're not suffering anymore, right? Obviously this isn't saying autism or down syndrome, because they're the least dangerous of all disabilities, as in, the life expectancies aren't 13 like Progeria. I absolutely hate ignorance coming from parent's because they only want their child to live so they don't have to go through grieving over their child. Certain disabilities effect how a child will live, and hoping their child lives and not understanding what they're going through is nuts. They may say they're doing good, but deep down they're suffering and only time will tell. :)
author: SS Shadow

text: SS Shadow thanks for your insight - yeah it‚Äôs better that they don‚Äôt suffer in the first place, but until their suffering isn‚Äôt a reality (through gene research and modification), giving our love, support and care to them is all we can do. Striving to live in a world which doesn‚Äôt experience the pain that they go through, is what we can do. Hoping for a brighter and more beautiful future is what we owe them, and ourselves. They teach us that as able bodied humans we can do everything that they try to, without anywhere near the amount of difficulty that they experience. While we sit around feeling sorry for ourselves, there‚Äôs a disabled kid wiping away their tears while moving forward with a task that‚Äôs seemingly impossible. I could go on but I‚Äôm not sure you‚Äôre going to understand this, until you do. I just wanted to share some insight, and received a lot more insight myself, so thank you.

author: Anna Helena

text:
It's only logical you feel that way. You are born worthy and you are always worthy, but life teaches you differently. 

The world around you has been sending you messages that you are not yet worthy until you earn, prove, or justify your existence. We are all constantly subjected to the message that we are not good enough, that we need to do more and be more and have more before we will truly be worthy. 

I have news for everyone: you are inherently worthy of existence. You are here, that is proof enough. You have been given the miracle of a physical body! 

Have you ever asked yourself why you are in your body and not someone else's? Have you ever asked yourself if you are actually or in your body, or if instead your body is in you? (Is awareness inside a body, or are there only sensations in awareness that imply a conceptual body? Close your eyes and check for yourself.) 

That may be too much - just see that you are worthy and nothing you could ever do could change that. You are a gift to the world, all of you. And the world is your gift to yourself.

text: One's person's hard is another person's daily life, I've put up with that scenario for a long time, and I don't blame nor discriminate against someone's experiences, I've had a relatively hard life compared to others I think it's fair to say. If someone said to me "Oh my god I'm having the worst time at the minute" I wouldn't berate them or say "walk a mile in my shoe's" I empathise because i've been through the same or had worse, but if said person has had a good life, or happy life then in my experience the down times seem to get to them easier because they aren't used to it and that's okay, can't blame them for that. That's my opinion anyway take it as you will.

text:
Thank you for missing the entire point of the TED Talk.

Sam was born with a rare mutation, but he didn't spend time thinking, "Oh, I'm suffering, poor me." He's thinking about what he can do, how he can achieve his dreams and goals as best he can despite the obstacles placed before him.

Did he have it rougher than most, certainly. But responding by saying that eugenics is the answer (despite the fact that it has been used throughout its inception to deride and demoralize other groups purely based on their genes) and that he is a genetic reject that shouldn't have existed is quite frankly defeating the hope that had in himself and the same hope that he hoped to bestow onto others.

He led a fulfilling life despite his condition and saying that he shouldn't have existed is equivalent to saying that anyone who isn't "normal" is automatically a failure from birth.

He was here to inspire, not pity himself or others. Think about that.

author: ExplosiveWaffulz

text: the x-axis determines where one feels about economic issues, left= more regulation, social welfare etc. while the right= less gov't regulation on buisness in order to establish freer markets. The y-axis determines social issues, up =authoritarian (more control over the individual for pragmatic overall outcomes), while down= freedom for people to make their own choices regardless of how much it may hurt them. Given that you can now generally determine what the colors would mean. Those residing in the purple category tend to believe in smaller governments and less control over individuals

author: befosocial

text:
I wish he wasn't immortal, but I wish he lived long enough just like a human being. It's good AND not good to be immortal for a few reasons:

The downsides
1. When you keep aging, your parents and friends will pass away and you won't be able to see them anymore.
2. Eventually there will be future disasters leading to the Earth, possibly if more asteroids, meteorites, or other things come from space.
3. If he was immortal, he'd have to be here for World War III or possibly World War IV. 
4. If I was him, I'd just like to live up to 2100 or 2200, to see how much we've succeeded since the 20th and 21st century. I would not want to go to the 24th century. 
5. You literally will be alive forever, that means you live for quintillions of years... If humanity goes extinct, you'll be the last one.

The upsides
1. If you're immortal, you can live through anything. You can fall 1000 feet and even survive, you can live through a gunshot, etc.
2. You'll be here to witness the first official contact between humans and aliens. That will change humanity forever, it's going to be a big impact on history.
3. I already said this once, but you're technically invincible... If a meteorite crashed onto you, you'd survive. You can't feel pain anymore.
4. You get to see how much our world has improved; 1900s-2100.
5. See humanity spread across the stars, if we'll be able to colonize on Mars or possibly the Moon. 
6. You won't have to witness death.

text: Ed P I disagree, I believe that Jesus (Who is both the Son of God and part of the Triune God: Father, Son, and Holy Spirit) died and rose again to pay for our sins and provide us a way (the only way) to Heaven. No one deserves Heaven, but if we repent and ask God to guide our lives, we can find the best this world has to offer, and hope for the future. It is not a religion but a relationship with the one true God. The soul doesn‚Äôt die, but will live on either with God or apart from Him, if that is what we want. If you choose not to believe that there is really a God and the Bible really is true, and that all of the laws of physics and the wonders of the universe the vastness of varieties of plant and animal life just happened all by themselves with no one to create them, you certainly may. He will not force Himself on you - you just may not be one of His. But just know that if u choose to be He is only a prayer away. He offers salvation to all that wish to be saved.
author: Cindy Seymour

text:
@Fat Man 1) Christ died for you
2) suffering is a blessing, in which Christ reveals himself. It is up to you to live every situation of your life with or without Jesus.
Of course, that is not easy, because to do that you have to trust God and have experienced his love and his mercy.
How to do that? Give God a chance and try to live the gospel in your life, trust me, it's worth it
author: Emanuele Feola

text: @Cindy Seymour Heaven is a nice thought most of the time, but it makes existence seem inescapable which could become a bad thing after a while. The meaning of life and what happens after we die are some of the biggest questions ever which nobody could possibly know. Christianity is a good religion in my eyes, but there has been nothing to make me believe in it.
author: Fat Man

text: @Emanuele Feola Unless I see a ghost or have a near death experience, I'm not going to become religious. I believe it others nothing but hope, which is good until after death there is nothing. author: Rafaela Guerra

text: @Rafaela Guerra Many find Jesus insignificant and Christian teachings to be too traditional which is why Christianity has shrunk in the West in comparison to earlier ages. I agree with many of these teachings and old world norms, however do not wish to devote my life to Him. I don't want to immediately assume there is a life after death, but rather explore different philosophical ideas and maybe eventually come to a conclusion later in my life or just wait until death. In my opinion, it is better to find out then. I don't wish for anything out of Jesus, even if He is real. Continue believing in Him if it is important to you. I respect Christianity though I would prefer to wait myself and see if He has anything to offer directly to reassure me that there truly is a life after death and I am not spending my time on something which may not even exist.

You can say he's not old enough to give life advice, but as long as you know you're happy with your life, you can try and tell other people how to be happy... obviously you're not very happy with yours due to the fact that you had to comment and degrade other people's lives to the point of calling them anything but human...

text: I completely agree that a shallow empathy disconnected of yourself is pretty dumb and probably awkward, but I do believe you have to empathize (unless I'm missing the english meaning, like is empathy necessarily condescendent ? ) to understand how he's saying about courage. I mean that you shouldn't treat his emotions differently than yours, bur you have to try to understand the challenges he faces, if they're different of yours, to be able to see if he is brave indeed and thus true to his word.
author: Antonio Vianna santos

text:
I did not say don't show him empathy, rather i said he doesn't need it and probably does not want it. What i was trying to say is that bt showering him with sympathy make make him feel like he is being treated differently when all he wants is to fit in a live a normal life. Ofc we should support him and help him, pray for him etc. but we should also make him feel human and treat him as we would treat a friend. 

He must get sick and tired of all the 'oh it must be so difficult' 'oh im so sorry for you'. It's complicated and my argument is very much flawed i agree. I think emotion just got the better of me when i was writing that comment. 

Bottom line is, yes we should shown him empathy and have sympathy. But also important is to treat him like a normal person and normal human being because that may be most important to him. I realise he has passed, but the amount he has achieved in his lifetime is way more than >90% of the worlds population so he can feel very proud of himself wherever he is now. Life will always be cruel, but we want to do our best to help fellow human beings actually live!

text:
Honestly I don't think it's right to call someone 'bad' or 'good'. Nobody is entirely bad or good; to some people their amazing af and to others they might be a complete nightmare. Now about her using the term 'retards'; just like all of you, she was expressing her own opinion. You might call her low and such but I honestly don't think there was a problem. I'm pretty sure all of you have used such terms when you wanted express your opinions. She used it because she was disappointed at how people reacted to this video; so don't be disgusted by her just because she said that. Honestly, some of you are over-reacting.

Not Applicable Evil is was not created by God, one of his angels turned into pure evil. Jealousy and hatred. The fallen angels name is satan. And he wanted to be God. He wanted power beyond anything imaginable. So God banished him from the kingdom of Heaven. But satan took his own path of evil and wanted to make those who believed in God miserable. God is all knowing, all-mighty and has power over everything. We do not. But we make evil decisions. Not God. So therefore God does not change the direction we are going because we knew the decision we were making. And we cannot blame God for not stopping us from OUR bad decisions. And because of our decisions lacking any thoughts of the Lord, the world is know full of bad people. You know so much about the Lord but you think that He created evil? You think he lets us suffer? He does not. We learn by seeing the regrets of our bad decisions. But evil only exists because we let it. If we all lived Godly lives, there would be no evil. 
Heaven, of course, lacks evil. You go to Heaven when you trust and believe in God. 
Do you trust God the way you should? If you believe that God created evil, your doubting God's way of life for you.

I want to be honest here. I think this comment is out of most comments here one of the best. Not because I¬¥m an asshole, but because he is following Sams advice. It doesn¬¥t matter if he¬¥s beautiful or not, this would be the same joke as when you¬¥d call someone (commonly considered) beautiful ugly. It¬¥s something people can laugh about. I¬¥m not saying that it is good as a joke, but that it is way better than all the people here making others sad and feel bad. Sam never wanted to be pitied, which he said in this talk, yet here they are saying things like, and I recite: "Poor kid he died one year later". 

Then there¬¥s people here telling everyone to stop reading the comments. These I don¬¥t like as well, as you will never learn how peoples thinking work without knowing of their thoughts in the first place. You can¬¥t just filter the bad stuff people say out and ignore it, in other words, be ignorant.

Then there¬¥s people like me, judging others for their comments. I don¬¥t personally think you should do that quite in the way most people do, and I don¬¥t even think I¬¥m doing it right. But it is once again, as stated before, a part of a whole.

There are tons more I could say, but honestly, I¬¥m too lazy. Most people are too lazy to type something.
But please.
Don¬¥t be too lazy...

To think.


- AMS

author: idk who I am

text:
Oh boy...
It's not a phrase. Saying someone lived longer literally means they lived for a longer period of time. "He lived a fuller, happier, and wiser life than those who lived up to age 70" is a phrase, and one that makes sense. It uses qualitative words; "fuller", "happier" cannot be measured quantitatively. "Longer" is a quantitative word; 10 cm is longer than 5 cm, 5 years is longer than 4 years, etc., and to suggest that you can use the word metaphorically defies all logic and English convention.

Now, you can say "it's as if he lived longer", or any supporting qualitative phrases to support the statement.

It's like saying "the marathon is 5km long, yet it was longer than 10km". Doesn't make sense. It would make sense to say "the marathon is 5km long, but it feels as if it's longer than 10km". 

And yes, we all know what the original poster was trying to say. But please, don't defend improper English. Accepting you're wrong is not a bad thing, and you'll learn a lot more from admitting your mistakes instead of saying, "well, it was close enough, so therefore it's correct". That way, you doesn't end up writing improper English in a place where it actually matters, not just a YouTube comment.

Basic linguistics aside, I love how all the people "defending" against the troll are spreading just as much negativity as the troll himself. No wonder Trump is president.

text:
To all the people who are unable to comprehend double meanings and say this doesn't make sense
To Live can be seen in the way of actually being alive, yes, but it can also be seen in the way of truly living your life and being happy with it and living to your highest potential
Sort of like the saying "everybody dies, but not everybody lives"
Not everyone is happy and appreciates what they have, they are so caught up in petty things, they do not truly take the time to live their lives, live in the moment, and be happy with what they were blessed with. 
In this way, to live means to chase your goals, have fun, make friends, find love, make mistakes, live in those unforgettable moments, but above all, be happy.
Very few of us can truthfully say we live our lives as happily as this beautiful soul did

author: Ramiro Basone

text:
(First off, if you don't feel this way anymore since its been a month, then yay, glad you are doing better and also sorry for the waste of time. If not hopefully I can say something that helps?)
I gotta say, I'm a bit of a nihilist and I know what you mean, sometime happiness seems to elude me for...weeks on end. Especially during stressful times in my life can really... escalate the despair. However there are ways to help yourself. If you have any people you could talk to or confide in, I know that can certainly help. For me I notice that talking through all my bullshit can help my collect my thoughts into something coherent, and at least relives some of the pressure. Also you need to know that there IS a way to get past such negative thoughts, and that you can be happy again. Like you were happy before in your life, you will be happy again later. At least if you work for it and try to better yourself. So um, sorry for the ramblyness, and I hope you feel better or are atleast on a path to feeling better. Good luck!

text: pemi sherpa Add meaning and purpose to all that you do. Especially the things you love, care about, and hold a deep passion for. Set goals and dreams for yourself, and work towards them and use them as a driving force. Look for, and try to find the good in this world, and open up your mind to love - not hate. Remember it's ok to cry and laugh and get emotional - we're humans, and no other creature can communicate/express our feelings anything close to the way we can. Just live life like you're a kid, loving what they love, without a care in the world, and loving it with all their heart.

text: @Luk√°≈° Dohnal Trolling is a bit of an exaggeration, but that is an interesting theory.
author: Luminous Dark

text:
I know it was an exaggeration, and I used the word in that spirit.

My "theory" (I wouldn't call it that) is based on the fact that I do not believe in the existence of free (FREE) will. I believe in causality, as that is what we observe in the world (a specific cause always brings about one specific result), and I believe that the workings of human brain are no exception to causality. So, I believe that a human behavior is exactly determined by causality; a combination of genetics ("hardware") and it's interaction with it's surroundings, which it doesn't a priori choose and which produces all that is not initially present, except the most basic things ("software"). Of course, at a certain point in time, a conscious choice appears, which further influences what "outside influences" the brain comes into contact with and thus how it develops further, but all those choices are built in a prior basis which we do not freely choose, and thus consequently we have no REAL freedom in this development.

As Arthur Schopenhauer said, "A man can do what he wills, but he cannot will what he wills.". And as Gustav Meyrink said it one of his stories: "See, you cannot 'want'. There are wishes beyond your will, some of which you know and some which you don't. And both are stronger than you."

For these reasons, I do not believe in the existence of something that you could call "ultimate, objective moral responsibility", because I believe that ultimately, there is no true choice. I believe we are, in fact, just witnesses of what happens, because nothing else than what will happen could possibly happen.

Possibly, if the brain somewhat worked on a quantum basis (if it made use of the state of superposition somehow in decision making), then that would refute this kind of determinism, but I don't think we know that's the case yet. And still, if the result of superposition was "truly random" (not just statistically random), I am not sure that it would prove "free will" in the classical sense - as randomness would probably not be considered a manifestation of "free will" by most people.
author: Luk√°≈° Dohnal

text: @Luk√°≈° Dohnal That is why I never get mad at people. Because if they didn't do it someone else would have most likely.
author: That's what I said, Bunny Bread.

text: I don't see how that conclusion stems from what I wrote, if you meant to imply that it does that is. What you said there would more logically stem from the assumption of the existence of infinite parallel universes for every possibility, but I don't think it stems from my deterministic view. My view is that nothing else than what happened could have happened. That includes the person who did a certain action. In other words, no other person could have done what has been done than the person who had actually done it.
author: Luk√°≈° Dohnal

text: I'm serious.
author: Luminous Dark

text:
@Luminous Dark 
My words are nothing more than arbitrary structures made of arbitrary symbols, yet you can understand them. Casualty doesn't account for memetic transferrence of these concepts, as that would imply that the words that I am typing and the words that you hear are nothing more than a complex hardwritten cue not open to interpretation for you to go about solely one action. 

Why do some concepts stick around and others wither and die? Why do some things "make sense" and others don't?

Casualty just seems extremely improbable, especially since it is self aware.
author: Internet Person

text:
"My words are nothing more than arbitrary structures made of arbitrary symbols, yet you can understand them. Casualty doesn't account for memetic transferrence of these concepts, as that would imply that the words that I am typing and the words that you hear are nothing more than a complex hardwritten cue not open to interpretation for you to go about solely one action."

You seem to assume that the brain's functioning is excerpt from the law of causality. I do not, which is why I don't see any contradiction. IMHO, when the brain perceives a symbol of communication such as a word or a sentence, it assigns meaning to them, but not randomly; the assigned meaning is determined by objective factors, like for example prior knowledge or IQ (simplified example, not saying that IQ is or isn't an accurate measure of "intelligence"). ... Since a huge amount of functioning of the brain takes place at sub-conscious level, we are not aware of all the causal processes that lead us to interpret a certain word in this way or that way, but I still consider it "safer" to assume that there are causal processes, like we observe in 99% of the workings of this universe (the 1% is not necessarily non-causal, but we are currently unable to determine the causes and make reliable predictions), than to assume that just because we don't yet understand the intricacies of inner workings of a certain system, the system is probably non-causal (or even that there is something like "free will", which is a problematic term on it's own, due to the fact that it is not a coherent and clearly defined concept).

By the way - in essence, not just words, but pretty much anything that we perceive with the senses is a symbol. What we see may not at all be the "true objective form" of the given object, but merely a symbolic representation of it that is possible for our senses to grasp, and which tells us how we are "supposed to" behave (or rather, it tells us what will probably happen if we chose this action or that action). Because an information does not have to be necessarily "true" (even if there was something like "objective truth") in order to bring about the desired result.
author: Luk√°≈° Dohnal

text:
@Luk√°≈° Dohnal So, what you are saying is "its complicated, so it is casualty".

Thanks but no thanks.
author: Internet Person

text: I am assuming that there is a cause, because we observe it everywhere else in structures and systems, that are simpler than our brain. We also observe it in the brain itself, although we do not observe the full spectrum of the causality. Combined with the fact that there is unconscious content in our minds, it seems very likely to me that the part which we don't observe is not "free will" (whatever that even is), but merely causes that we are not aware of.
author: Luk√°≈° Dohnal

text: It seems more likely and plausible to me than to suggest that our decisions are actions are not determined by prior causes, i.e. that they are "truly random". (I don't see any room for "free will" in between "causal" and "truly random")
author: Luk√°≈° Dohnal

author: Yukimura Toru

text: Retro Gaming Firstly, yes. The way he overcomes his disability daily is absolutely inspiring. Unbelivably inspiring. As it should be. And if you can't see that, it's your problem. Because I look at someone with a disability and that disability is apparent to me does not make me a bad person. It makes me realistic. There is nothing noble about ignoring such an obvious handicap. There is something to be said however, for seeing a handicap and then being able to look past it and seeing that how an individual handles their handicap so well and so optimistically absolutely adds to the inspiration, not detracts from it. The fact that I can look at him as an entire individual, as a whole, disability and all, is not a fault. It's part of what makes him who he is. And though it's not the only part, not by a long shot, I would venture to say it's a pretty damn big part.  Secondly, he would be inspiring even without the disability. The kid is 17 and speaks with the intelligence and eloquence of someone twice his age or older. His maturity and world view are admirable qualities. So get off your high horse and don't make insinuations about why I would consider him an inspiration, when the truth is you don't have the vaguest notion as to what I find inspiring about this young man. Take your nonsense elsewhere.
author: Brandon J

text: @Brandon J I was referencing your value to his maturity in relation to his disability, not to how he is inspiring. He is inspiring, and I was inspired by him because of his unbelievable strength and optimistic behavior. But he speaks exactly like many people around my age, 15-18, and I have seen many people younger than him speak that way and people are saying that he's mature when they aren't really looking at his maturity but the fact that he's on Ted talks and has a disability. It just annoyed me because people don't compare his maturity to a general population and instead say he's mature because of a disability. Just scroll down the comment section, many people are saying the exact same thing you originally said when it doesn't matter and it, again, annoyed me.
author: Yukimura Toru

text: Retro Gaming That's patently ridiculous. I wasn't tying his maturity to his disability. And nothing I wrote should've led you to that conclusion. If you speak eloquently, then I congratulate you. But if you believe most kids that age speak so verbosely and with such diction, then you're naive. I have younger brothers and younger cousins around the same age and very few of them speak so well. I know relatively few adults that speak English the way it's meant to be spoken.
author: Brandon J

text: Brandon J Then I guess we just have different comparatives based on our own experiences with age-similar people.

text: go on here? im interested ...i may fall into this trap when i really am infact depressed but i try my very best to focus on the present and be thankful for the present it is. i try to send joy to all and not focus on what i dont have which makes me think maybe im just limiting myself? no longer forming such opinions and mindsets about the things i dont have and basically ignore and push them off in a primitive mindset driven by fear? Il place n example one of many....Im 24 i make a decent living as a journeyman  but i feel its not enough to get by...im a virgin who doesnt  go out much due to finance. If i ever talk to a girl i cant tell wether or not they are being friendly or hitting on me so i dont feel its appropriate to touch or make a move on them i feel thats harrassement (again fear driven).  I fear even if a girl liked me i could never give her what she deserves so shes better finding someone who can again finance. When it comes to children i dont feel its fair to bring children into this world i cant financially fend for n give a good life unlike the unhappy one iv been living basing it all off finance( again fear). Again though im numb to the idea because i cant tell wether a girl is being friendly or hitting on me so i dont form an opinion that she may or may not be interested me which is upsetting because end of the day itd be nice to at least be friends with girls but i find it hard because of the physically attraction i have towards them so again out of fear id never feel its appropriate to ask a girl to chill iv chilled with girls before gone out but thats because they asked but again i learned from experience when i thought they were interested they were infact just being mentally n physically friendly n didnt mean anything by it (not to mean i was a lil bitch being clingy n told em i was interested in them.... just making physical contact sexually but not actual sex) led me on as to what  i thought they might have been interested just to learn their just being friendly so thats one example maybe i am depressed trying to convince myself but i have a lot of hope

text:
Happiness is a choice. As opposed to you, who is clearly miserable, he knew he could die anyday and that he in fact was going to die soon, so he chose to enjoy what he could. 
You're miserable because you lack direction and think you'll live for a long time, and somehow you convince yourself everyday that someday things might change, that it can wait... Because you don't make the choice of being happy, which would lead you to do things that make you happy, you continue to be miserable and see the negative in all things, as you did here.
Don't take it as an insult, take it as a push in the right direction.
Remember its your life to live, one else's.

author: Comic Sam

text:
Tim Slee First of all, your examples are all over the place and make no sense; the first two are obviously sarcastic and somewhat understandable, but the third one simply exhibits your lack of understanding of the concept of "suffering for God", and finally the fourth contradicts itself.

Second, please respond with actual scientific proof that God doesn't exist.  If you can't do this, then how about logical?  Keep in mind, however, that I'm not talking about "people suffer in the world and if God were real he wouldn't let that happen".  I would explain why this is such a stupid comeback, but this comment is already an essay and I'm not sure you would even be willing to read it.
author: Comic Sam

text: @Comic Sam Look what we've got here. A smart-ass. If one brings up something with no factual evidence (like the teapot going around the sun) and tells another person to scientifically disprove it, they are stupid. Now go and pray to your loving little god who cares so much about your little life.
author: Tim Slee

text: Tim Slee I would like to know how asking for proof that God doesn't exist makes me stupid.  Since you evidently lack the reasoning skills to figure it out, the purpose of the question was to point out how, though God's existence may be impossible to prove, so too is it impossible to prove otherwise.  I also see how you avoided my question by slinging insults in my face.  Such is the behavior of a man who knows he has been outdone.

author: The Voodoos

text: We'll keep our heads in the sand as long as we can feasibly do so, I hope I live to see all of the ignorant people accept it and grovel at the feet of people who were lobbying for change they rejected 30 years ago, but I don't think I really want to, since at that point it's probably a bit too late, might be too late now, depends on the Arctic shelf's methane gas level , and if it's been released yet.
author: Discordant harmony

text:
@Death
¬†Well the Paris climate agreement is unrealistic if one looks at the maths regarding the future safe World average temperature or CO2 emissions Humans world wide are dependent on production and consuming our biosphere is at breaking point regarding methane in the Arctic sea and permafrost including Siberia early indications don`t look good one of many feedback loops.The northern hemisphere jet streams will no doubt bring added problems.? The argument that CO2 will promote tree and plant life is nonsensical 55 million years ago plant life adapted over long periods of time the forest topsoil became rich in nutrients and was much deeper than today's world rain forests our coal deposits are a testament to that adding CO2 without extra water and nutrients has the opposite effect on most plant life and trees being they die-back.Freshwater i fear will be an escalating problem in certain parts of the World.The question is can humankind around the world move forward as one united race to solve this problem.? Looking back at human history to this very day i am doubtful.But there is always hope¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† .. ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬†
author: The Voodoos

text: To further compound the issue, with the release of the Arctic shelf's methane stores, the pH levels in the oceans will be so great, that only sulfate reducing bacteria can feasibly survive, bacteria, that exhale hydrogen sulfide, which happens to be toxic to plants and animals, and also a greenhouse gas, the prospects are grim indeed.
author: Discordant harmony

text:
@Death
¬†Well there are some radical on the table geoengineering proposals coming out of the woodwork so to speak.It seems many scientist from around the World are coming to the opinion that solutions will be needed to draw-down CO2 from the atmosphere anyway even if we stopped our fossil fuel addiction today. Realistically the Worlds country's CO2 forthcoming targets from the Paris conference will be something of a challenge to say the least.Regarding methane it is assumed that in the worst case, with a steady warming of the ocean of 3 degrees Celsius, around 85 per cent of the methane trapped in the sea floor could be released into the water column. Other, more sensitive models predict that methane hydrates at great water depths are not threatened by warming. According to these models, only the methane hydrates that are located directly at the boundaries of the stability zones would be primarily affected. At these locations, a temperature increase of only 1 degree ¬≠Celsius would be sufficient to release large amounts of methane from the hydrates. The methane hydrates in the open ocean at around 500 meters of water depth, and deposits in the shallow regions of the Arctic would mainly be affected.(World ocean review) Whats on my mind is the Worlds food security.? ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬†¬†
author: The Voodoos

text:
Food will be a problem for sure, without some innovations in the field, and considering petroleum is the reason we can even support our numbers, which continue to grow, it's going to be tough. but, I'd like to think we'll make a good effort at it when it becomes readily apparent to everyone, of course. At which point it's a bit too late.

This is a particularly tricky issue, because of how entrenched we are in oil and it's derivatives, lots of lives on the balance, even a successful weaning and rectifying of the co2 levels could be quite deadly to many people, especially those in first world countries.


What did the Paris conference propose, I haven't been keeping up.
author: Discordant harmony

text:
@Death
¬†The universal agreement from the pairs conference main aim is to keep global temperature rise this century well below 2 degrees Celsius and to drive efforts to limit the temperature increase even further to 1.5 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels I think by 2024 we will be at 1.5 if not above in my mind they moved the problem to the future like 85 years.Regarding your point first world countries (weaning and rectifying of the co2 levels could be quite deadly) to implement the infrastructure and completely change the way we live our lives will be similar to living life like the ...¬†¬† Little House on the Prairie.However 7.448,924,564,People cant live like that due to many reasons.By the way the worlds population figure has just increased by the time you read this comment.It makes a person think if this world had not been blessed or cursed depending on which way you look at it? with fossil fuels imagine there had been no oil or coal,? certainly it would be a different World than we see around us now.I wonder if people could have been more happier.?¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬†
author: The Voodoos

text:
@Death
¬†P.S i forgot to mention the Paris agreement also recommends or expects CO2 to be kept below 450ppm i think this is a unrealistic figure as at present we are at 402.24 ppm giving the factor that we will be approaching 4ppm each year and possible more bearing in mind countries that have promised to reduce. But there is no enforcement or fine Its a dam mess if you ask me.If a country has a choice between economic growth or reducing CO2 emissions what do you think it will chose.? I think the only positive thing coming out of the Paris agreement if you can call it an agreement is climate change is now internationally recognized as a serious problem.¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬†

text:
'Here is my simple example. Its not the point that everyday 22,000 children die through lack of clean water food or medication and because one knows this fact the world is a worse place."

I'm confused, are you saying that if those 22000 people didn't die, the world wouldn't be a better place? How is someone having no knowledge of something indicative of the ,.... er.... worseness(?) of the plight? You have knowledge of it anyway, and i do too.

"Its the fact that less than 00.5 % of all money worldwide spent on armament manufacturers for humans to kill each-other could save all those children's lives that`s what makes this world a worse place."

That's the issue with your stance, it's easy to combat. Picture a world where that 00.5% of the armaments are used to kill more children, bam, a worse world. Picture a world ravaged by nuclear warfare, bam, a worse world. And so on.

"Tell me i am curious you say and i quote (The disgusting nature of individual acts in the past is not relevant to the overall current condition of the world today) so you think those people spending life term sentences in prisons around the world are what.?"

People not effecting the status of the world today, except for whatever resources they use.

"for the most part"  Go on.

text:
@dreams of turtles
All humans by their nature are flawed animals -- in some way. There is no such thing as a
perfect DNA construct .
Large numbers are physically impaired but even larger numbers are mentally & emotionally impaired .
I would never attempt to lecture anyone about
an abusive upbringing -- but what I would say is that recognising that you had a flawed home life puts you well ahead of the posse --
many of whom don't even want to admit their failings. Admit you are not perfect .
Accept it and get on with life. Overcome what you see as YOUR PROBLEM by embracing
Charity and Love . Giving just those things to¬† deserving humans and animals you meet¬† ,will heal your the cracks in your own makeup and quickly make you whole again .

text:
That's no excuse for undue suffering, let's say, I rape your children and kill them in the most painful way imaginable , but it's okay, I'm not doing anything wrong because they'll go to heaven. 

Since you don't seem to get the logic , I'll spell it out simply.

God is sitting on his couch,  jerking off to angel porn or whatever(because he doesn't think masturbation is actually wrong,he just likes to see humans squirm against their nature because he's a sick fuck :3)

He gets bored after a while, so he creates the earth, universe, people, and he says to them "alright guys, be fruitful and multiply, this garden is yours, except that fruit, it's forbidden,  so don't eat it(cause like anyone who has any knowledge of human psychology knows, that always works) .

So, as is human nature(the serpent shit is really unnecessary, they'd eat it regardless) they eat it, and God says "You done goofed, so, I'm going to punish not just you, but everyone who comes after you"

At which they should say "Why are you punishing those who come after with the possibility of unnecessary pain and suffering, in fact, you are all powerful, why do you allow the fruit to exist at all, or the serpent? If you're all powerful, just cure all suffering yourself, and make everyone know you did it, and they'll all follow your rules without fail?"

Because he's testing you? There doesn't need to be a test, he's god, and all powerful, so he already knows how each individual will respond to things in their life.

author: Petra Quartz

text:
@Death
Since you won't listen to my arguments I am going to end this debate here. You won't burn for eternity if you go to hell - the Bible and apostolic tradition both hold that hell is the destruction of the soul. In other words, your soul will die in hell and you will cease to exist. God gives us the choice to renounce Him or join Him. I have read up on my theology and know that the Christian God is pure and loving. I don't think you understand that. Personally, I want to worship Him for an eternity, but if you don't then that is entirely your choice and you can die in hell. I wish you wouldn't, God wishes you wouldn't (but He will let you because free will is one of His gifts and He wants actual love, not coerced love), millions of Christians wish you wouldn't, all the Saints wish you wouldn't, but you seem pretty stubborn. Just know that I used to have the exact same opinion as you (rather face eternal torment than spend eternity with Somebody who would let bad things happen), but it changed quickly after even minor research into theology. So don't go whining on the Internet about the "problem of evil" if you haven't spend a single calorie of energy towards learning about it for yourself. That is all, I wish you well.
author: Cole Guadenine

text:
That's because your argument is null, logically speaking, you no doubt condone imprisonment of people who commit acts of violence against others? Ok, We'll say you do until you say otherwise, with your logic, why? No matter what heinous crimes they commit, why? 

When in your belief system they will already undergo the great possible punishment, why is god immune to the same persecution? He created humans, made their psychology, bodies, tendencies ,etc, so, why would he create the fruit or allow the serpent to exist? What part of all powerful don't you get? 

You cannot hope to convince me that the suffering in this world is paltry, nor that God couldn't stop it if he wanted to, which means he exercises his own free will, and chooses not to help some, to visit upon some more suffering than is necessary, more than others, indeed, he's all powerful, any suffering is unnecessary.

Sure, like the argument you made, god didn't visit it, Adam and Eve did, but, since he can stop it, he did visit it, to see a rape and not try and stop it when you could easily do so, is to condone it.


Whatever, this  has been stimulating, and i appreciate that you kept your mind sound in the face of adversity upon your faith, more than most do on the Internet.

text:
I don't think that wishing someone else to die, even if he made such an offensive comment, make you better than he or more mature from my point of view. I can't even imagine why you wrote that, it's not like if +TheAmazingCrusader will change his mind just because you call him a "piece of shit", even I don't expect you to change your mind about the comments you do on the internet by reading this. It's just that, as the way I see things, your comment is as negative as his, even worst since you called him "son of a bitch", "cold hearted", "inhuman", "piece of shit", "childish person" and you wished him to die.

You feel like the death of Sam is too heartbreaking, but I don't think that even if he were alive he would care about someone calling him "ugly" (which he is by the way, for beauty standards). Well, I find heartbreaking you wishing someone else to die, someone that is alive, that may have brothers, a mother, a father.

I wish you a lot of peace and love my dear The Rising_ Ninja, to you and to everyone no matter the kind of comment you made :) <3

author: Raidis De Jesus

text: +Raidis Jhonderis De Jesus Baez Well, thank Jehova google translate exists. In my opinion having emotional crutches is a bad thing for both you and your 'crutches'. For you it's bad because one day inevitably they will disappear and you will collapse. And for your 'cruthes' in the face of family and friends it's bad because you USE them for your wellbeing. You just uncosciously assign certain duties to those people and you expect from them to take care of you. It's a two-way manipulation process which leads to nowhere. And on the Jehovah issue, I don't believe in any humanlike creature sitting somewhere creating universes and looking after 1 000 0000 00 0 00 00 00 0 00 000 0 00000 living creatures on earth with equal attention and love. What you call as God is the force of nature which I agree with you is absolutely self-sufficient and humans can only dream of state like this. I am talking of emotional self-sufficiency. Of course you are dependent on water, air, food, environment and many more factors which 'God' has transcended, but inner state of happiness should be 100% your responsibility and not delegated to 5 people around you.

text: And whoever thought this was a great talk isn't being honest with themselves and is speaking from emotion. It was a crappy talk. But that's no knock against the kid because he's only 17. Very few 17 year olds have anything noteworthy to say. It's super interesting to hear the perspective of a person struggling with such a rare disease, but at the end of the day the points he made are hardly  "ideas worth spreading". It's stuff that's been said a thousand times (accept what you can't change, focus on what you can change etc...). The people who disliked the talk aren't heartless, they're just honest enough to admit when something sucks, even if they feel bad for the person giving it

text:
@Craig Hauser We all know this. You are the one, who dont think further - and thats a moral shame. But i explain it to you. Few years ago , there was a stand-up-comedian, who makes a show, and put in few jokes about people who cant walk (no legs etc). There was two interesting consequences of that : 1) after that it was guys like YOU , who made big complains and bad critizm about the comedian... 2) the comedian get emails from blind people ( i mean people who cant see) , and they say to the comedian : 'please put in your next show also jokes about us' ...
I know, thats hard to understand for you, but to not make jokes about a minority IS ALSO a kind of discrimination, because : with that behavior YOU ampute this people from society .. because its a part of society to laugh with eachother , about eachother - and to oversaturate things (you heard about 'big bang theory' the show ? thats also a kind of oversaturating nerds... its clear that in real life THOSE kind of nerds DONT exist)...
Also Sascha Baron Cohen once was critized from guys like you because of his 'Borat'-character. They mean to him : 'Its an insult against kasachstan people..Borat let people know how stupid and non-evolved kasachstan people are' ... Wanna know how Sascha Cohen answered ? He answered: 'It only shows the stupidity of the people who THINKS that Borat represents Kasachstan people'
Thats a hard answer, and i dont want to mean it to you in our case...
But i think you know what i mean....
There is a difference : wether i make jokes about a minority about their condition , behaviors, etc ... OR i make jokes TO take away the human value of a human being. The difference is subtil, but its recognizable... and i give you a kind of roadmap how you can see the difference. For example, if i would say about this human being : 'Burn it with fire, before it lays eggs' .. thats not ok... also when i say things which shows a 'difference in human value' ...for example : 'use this creature for medical experiments' etc... Thats all things which are truely not ok and discrimination, even if someone wants it defend as 'funny' -because its clearly to see: that the reason why someone said such things weren't to be funny - it was there to try take away human value of a human being.
Also if someone would gather a bunch of people, just to laugh about one - thats mobbing/bulling ..also in that case the 'one' isnt integrated - he is seperated from the social group...

In our case: he was integrated. He knows about his condition, he knows that he looks in a different way... as long he is integrated in the society in the way : how he is, and how he looks (and that doesnt mean necessarly that 'everyone have to see optical beauty in him' - it means: as long he is valued how he is, as human beeing , there could no problem with it, to make jokes about outstanding impressions about him)... In the same way that also other public persons have no problem with it... there are a lot of impersonations by comedians from g.w.bush, al pacino, george freeman, etc (just look to frank caliendo ;) ). They all also can say : 'now im hurt' , but they didnt , because it isnt meant in a insulting way (they understand the difference). But with your logic, they also could be butthurt.

And that makes the difference... with our sense of humor, we integrated this guy in the video in our social life. He had the balls to make himself public - not with a mask - but how he is. He dont hide his appearence , and was prepared for all the reactions.. and what people make about his step to the public. It was very brave... and unfortunately he isnt alive anymore - but i think he also would smile about 'sloth from the goonies' jokes... in the same way that for sure G.W.Bush smiles about impersonations when frank Caliendo shows a 'dumb bush'... I'm sure, Caliendo still has big respect to Bush. Its all about: how someone mean a joke, and not : which joke someone makes about the other.
And like i say with the stand-up-comedian before: the interesting thing is: no amputed people had make complain about the ampute-jokes...the people who critized the comedian were people who had both legs, and didnt know: if its really hurted the people with no legs or not.

I know, you mean it in a good way.. I know you said your message because you care about minorities. I appreciate that..¬† But as i say: there is a difference how someone mean a joke, or wether he just try to take away human value from a human being....
author: PygmalionFaciebat

author: Young King

text:
@C LOAK
I disagree. Imagine how stupid the average person is. Just stop everything, and imagine how stupid the average person is for a minute.








Now, realize that half the people out there are even dumber than that.









Sam made intelligent decisions with his life, morales, and philosophy in the face of impossible odds. Thats what I'm getting at. Many teenagers kill themselves because someone shit talked them on the interwebs. Look what Sam went through, and he still lived a fulfilling happy life despite all the odds against him doing so. The teenyboppers today need safe zones and trigger warnings. 70 years ago people the same age as the spoiled filth we have today were storming the beaches of Normandy and killing NAZI's.

People today are just inferior humans.
author: Br!an Delta V

text:
@Joe Schmoe¬†"People today are just inferior humans."

The only difference between people today and the people who stormed beaches is that reality has changed around them.

At that time right and wrong were clearly defined FOR them by governments and parents.

Several more wars have happened since and it has become increasingly obvious that what politicians learned from WW2 wasn't that "war is hell" but that war is a political tool.

And the best part is that teens and young to middle aged adults are no longer forced to depend on the rhetoric. We can investigate on our own.

But if you genuinely believe that teens today are more spoiled than teens of 70 years ago, look at two phenomenon that should clarify things a bit for you:

The crowds of support both from and for New Yorkers in the aftermath of 9/11, and the eagerness of our youth to strike back at those who were responsible in Afghanistan.

Now look at your WW2 example of Normandy and keep something very clearly in your mind...Many of the troops who stormed that beach were only there because of the draft.

No-one had to force our youth to go to Afghanistan.¬†

I don't see this kid as being especially more intelligent.
I see him as having a perspective that is beyond human because of what he had to deal with in his life.

He didn't just think outside the box. He lived there.

And while many would allow it to turn them to mush, he took the time to contemplate.

He's not human.
He's better than that.

But then again...Maybe he was just more human than the rest of us.
author: corthew

text:
@corthew
I dont think its entirely true that kids then were there just for the draft. almost EVERYONE enlisted. Even 14 year old kids lied and forged their birth papers to enlist. I actually met one WW2 veteran not too long ago that did just that. He was too young to re-enlist. Whats the average 14 year old today look like? Some videogame addicted spoiled brat. Back then kids worked on farms and what not from the time they could stand.

I definitely can't argue with many of your sentiments, however the kids that enlisted after 9-11 were a minority. Definitely a farcry from the entire population between 14 and 25 trying to get in.

"But then again...Maybe he was just more human than the rest of us."
This is basically what I'm trying to get at.

text: I still think the words you're looking for are pity, or sympathy. I don't wanna be rude, but respect is something you give someone who has done something remarkable for you or the world. This guy was given an unfair disadvantage in life, and while he still struggled to make something of his life, he ultimately died very early in life. Perhaps you are implying that the respect you want to give him is for the powerful example and hope he offered the world, where his actions and speech showed us that even in the most hostile of conditions, one can push on and still walk on a stage and talk. (See my point ?) It's not that important, we all have hope. Hope is sometimes a curse ! We're not running out of hope, otherwise we would be dead. He also had hope. What is different, is that he had a terrible illness and we don't. Sympathy and pity are what you should feel towards him. Respect is when you have someone that has all the advantages, and STILL uses them for the betterment of the world and not for personal gain. Besides, people nowadays use "respect" for nearly anything, and I just wanted to point out how inconsistent this word has become.
author: Yama Koto

text: @Far Soneria¬†Thats just not true, I have a ton of respect for this person. I don't think you fully understand the meaning of the word, thats fine, your life experiences just haven't revealed what the true meaning of respect is.

You'll just be perceived as an uneducated immature douchebag that wastes time on social media. I wasn't going to waste my finger muscle on you when scrolling down the comments of this video , but after reading several of your comments, i changed my mind. Seeing that everyone else is inclined to calling you all these names and rude and whatnot , I personally think that it just fuels your actions. (obviously right?) But I got some downtime right about now, so i figure its a perfect time to get your attention. Bottom line bro, is that this dude Sam, is awesome . I somewhat knew a little bit about his story, and watching this video was a good therapy for me, and it should be as well for you. Just do everyone a favor and try to raise your self-esteem on a porn-site or facebook or twitter or instagram, somewhere else where its not actually MATERIAL THAT MATTERS like this video . I dont wish anything bad on you because it would just be, like i said, a waste of energy. Hopefully you take a little of what i am conveying to you AT LEAST with a grain of salt, maybe one day changing you for the better. Oh ! and by the way, what makes this guy better than you is that he loved his life. You dont clearly. Because if you did, you'd appreciate all the men and women that stick up for you and try to make this place a better place to live. You can do whatever the fuck you want in this life. You can disrespect your mom, degrade women be a nobody and be on here to talk shit. For what though? Listen to sam, love your family, go out with friends make a life out of what you have. Being on here only is reasoned through your desperation for attention. Come on mustacheboy, you can do it. Sam believes in you

+Lollipoper42   yes having a different mindset doesn't mean you make mindless decisions,  but my experience of many years in the church has shown me that many christians (as do people of other religions) DO make "mindless" decisions.  For example, making a decision they would not normally make based on prayer.

The comparison with scientists believing in ETs is not a good comparison at all.  Many scientists do believe in life on other planets (not necessarily complex life comparable to humans) because the probability is extremely high that this is the case.  It is a RATIONAL conclusion.  Where as belief in god and religious myths that have no real evidence are completely irrational.

After 25 years in the church, many of them as a fundamentalist,  i started to watch debates on youtube with the highest educated top scholars on both sides on topics such as "creation vs evolution", "does god exist", "theism vs atheism", etc etc.  After watching over 100 hours,  my chains were broken.  Start watching debates and lectures,  start watching episodes of "the athiest experience" (search for it on youtube) where they talk live and answer questions and comments from christians....  and see if you can still hold on to your faith when it's irrationality starts to be revealed to you.

Peace my friend

text:
+podoz First off you made a lot of really great points. Before I comment though, I wanted to recomment on why I compared "the existence of ET's" with (belief of) the "existence of God". I agree, hindsight being 20/20, that it was an unfair comparison because it didn't explain my reasoning behind it. My reasoning was that both sides (Atheists) and (Christians) see each idea as irrational, illogical, etc. Also the big difference between Christians and Atheists, is that Atheism look at most everything based on facts. Everything has to make sense and be proved by fact. (This is per my personal observation, please feel free to correct me!) Christianity, on the other hand is a combination of:
1. Facts that take a little faith:
If you think about it, these type of facts are in almost every part of life. Like how someone would know for a fact that their friend for example, is innocent of a crime based on a series of "circumstantial evidence" and well they know that person, even if the friend doesn't have a rock solid case. I know God exist because I can feel his presence when I'm praying to him.This to me is evidence. Circumstantial, but evidence all the same.¬†
2. Relationship:
This is the main factor that differs Christianity from Atheism. One can not believe in Christ (and God are one in the same), without wanting and engaging in a relationship with their all mighty father. Believe it or not, but that relationship is actually a lot more than just talking to an empty room on your knees with your hands folded. If we truly are willing to listen, our Father can and will speak back to us. It just may not always be in a "talking through a burning bush" or a "water to wine" kind of way. Sometimes, when we pray we are quick to blame God when we do not get the "perfect response" right away.¬†
author: Lollipoper42

text:
+Lollipoper42   I get what you say,  i've been there,  i was a "spirit filled" christian who had a "personal relationship" with christ.... etc etc for decades.   I used to say the same things you do.   But eventually,  those of us who actually do use the brains that "god gave us".... and question things,  start to see things very differently.  The evidence you speak of is not evidence at all....  "feelings" and "personal experiences" are evidence to you and you alone.  What good are they to someone else who can't feel or experience them, no matter how earnestly they try and desire to?  And to the many ex-christians such as myself who did "feel" and "experience" those things...  it's very easy to look back with "rational eyes" and see that yes they were "real" feelings and experiences, but they were "created" by us, internally.  There is no "god" necessary for delusion,  us humans are great at creating our delusions all on our own.

Regarding prayer and communication with our "father"....  any honest christian will come to realize over time that this is non existent.  The warm fuzzy feelings,  and the things that you THINK god is saying to you... is all you,  created in your brain,  by you,  but crediting it to god because that's what you want to believe.  When you pray for something and you don't get it.... it's ok,  it's not gods fault,  it's not HIS timing.... or he doesn't WANT me to have it so he can "teach" me something.... or he's "testing" me.... etc etc.  He always has an excuse (that you give him).   On the RARE time you get it...  it's something that may well have happened without god (ie. it was not a miracle).... but you are happy to give all the "glory" to god anyway.   Prayer is a scam.   There was even a scientific study done where they compared the outcome of people with cancer being healed.... one group was prayed for by sincere christians.... the other group was not prayed for.   This was a genuine study done with a large number of subjects.  The result.... no difference.   This is one of the MAJOR reasons christians lose their faith,  because over time they come to realize that prayer does nothing, makes no difference to outcomes,  and people get sick and tired of NOT "hearing" back from god in any kind of clear and certain way.  Forget about a "perfect" response as you say.... how about ANY response that you can know (not just think, hope, or believe, but KNOW is) clearly and certainly is from god.  It doesn't happen.  Rational christians eventually learn that prayer is simply a scam.

text:
+podoz I'm going to divide my response into sections if that's ok:

1. "Perfect Response" is whatever that person defines as a  "Reasonable Response". Just like if you were talking with a friend, sometimes you don't like the response they give. It is the same with God. Except this time, responses are be hidden in "His word" for example, or "The Holy Spirit". Waiting to be discovered by hearts that are genuine and open to change.  CBN's Seven Keys to Hearing God by Craig von Buseck, is a really great article for the subject. He says "The most difficult part of hearing God is the fact that it takes time to learn to discern God's voice -- and it takes a humble heart. Jeremiah 29:12-13 says, 'Then you will call upon Me and go and pray to Me, and I will listen to you. And you will seek Me and find Me, when you search for Me with all your heart'." Honestly, I'm afraid that may be the problem you mentioned, "instead the person praying will get no response -- or an occasional vague "feeling" or "sign" which he "interprets" (thinks, wishes, hopes) is from god". 
Whether or not you are including yourself in the scenario you stated, I've found that the reason people aren't "hearing" God is because they may not be seeking God with humble hearts. Please let me clarify. I am not saying that these people aren't genuinely seeking God._ What I am saying is that they may be are seeking out God for the wrong reasons. Some may be praying simply to feel good about themselves, something has been off the to-do list. Another reason, communication is breached, is because people often seem to have the need to to test God. However, there is no fooling him. I have a question for you. Would there ever have been a "reasonable response" from God that would satisfy you? Even if God spoke out as clear as someone else talking, Satan would masterfully convince you that it was all in your head and it wasn't God. So I ask isn't it possible that the question isn't whether or not God exists, but whether or not you really gave him a real chance?
You might be asking yourself, "Why are his responses hidden"? God camouflages his answers from those who don't intend on listening to his answers.
2. I just want to reassure you that I always took into account the fact that you were once Christian. I just know that even though you still have the physical knowledge from your Christian days, your point of view on them has drastically changeed to the point that you fufilled Ephesians 4:18, being darkened in their understanding, excluded from the life of God because of the ignorance that is in them, because of the hardness of their heart" 
3. You've made an incorrect assumtion about Christians here; "The non-rational christians won't question anything". Maybe that is how you lived out your "Christian life"  but I honestly don't know anyone who hasn't asked questions. However, I don't mean "questioning their faith. I mean asking questions, like How? What? Where? When in study with the Word. That's why when you look at a bible, it's marked up because that person spent time, daring to ask questions. That is how you know, they sre confident in their faith, when they sren't afraid to question their faith.

If you want to continue in a rational manner i'm happy to continue,  but i'm not the slightest bit interested in psycho babble or scripture that is utterly invalid and irrelevant.

A quick comment on faith,  as you mentioned it a few times in your last comment.  Faith is simply believing without evidence or proof.  Now if you tell me you have a dog,  i can believe you on faith,  because i know dogs exist and many people have dogs.  But if you tell me you have a flying talking dog....  i would need a whole lot of evidence before i believed it.  I would not believe on faith,  and most people would agree i would be stupid if i did.  If i did...  such faith would be no more than mere gullibility.  This is why every religious person is gullible (just as i was),  as they believe a fairy tale as fact

author: EyeAmBatman

text:
+P.S. ILoveGaming Well said. when we read comments though, i think we're ignoring a couple of things. first of all, people only comment if they feel that they should. when we see someone like sam, it opens up a bit of emotions that urges us to say something. when we see someone normal, there isn't much point complimenting them since we assume they get complimented enough already (maybe i don't know the exact reason here), but most of us just say nothing at all because we don't have an urge to. other people tend to post negative comments towards normal people for various reasons; jealousy, criticism, they're annoyed, etc. These emotions can be strong once they're triggered, so the urge to post negative comments is must stronger for those people than for the people who would have posted a compliment. So now we have a comment section full of people posting nasty things, and no one is saying anything nice, and you're left with the impression that no one actually likes this guy. But that's a false representation of how people really feel. most of the time when you look at the amount of comments, and the number of views, its about a 1/10 ratio, this video is close to 1/100. That means every time one person writes a negative comment, 10-100 people did not feel that strongly about the video. Again, usually it takes more effort to be impressed than it does to find fault. So no comments may actually be a good thing. 

Also, try to remember that there are kids of all ages that post here. Sometimes when you watch entertainment videos, you'll find tons of kids posting in the comment section. They're dumb and they don't know what they're saying, and you have no good way of knowing how old anyone here is. 

Sometimes i feel like Randy from My Name is Earl. I have no idea if people understand what i'm saying. i hope i didn't repeat myself into redundancy, and I hope you get the picture I'm trying to paint.
author: Hey Guys, This Is My New Name

author: MisterSir

text: @TeslasLoveChild I get what you're saying, when you used the word "emotionally" it was used in context with¬†people that let their emotions guide their ideology instead of using critical thinking as opposed¬†to people in general,¬†¬†Im just enjoying your vehemence and meticulously thought out responses..¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† There will be people that see the kid and act differently, more polite and act appropriately due to political correctness...An argument could be made that they are stupid and lazy, that they are changing their beliefs due to fear and being an outsider, but I believe those people aren't the general consensus, that they are few in numbers.. For instance, everybody knows people with some sort of disability and knows the struggles they endure and most of these people would appreciate a person taking the time to put an¬†important message out there for those trying to cope with the same hardships, so whether they are truly changing their beliefs or just looking at things from a different perspective from a more complex narrative ideology is another thing....
author: EyeAmBatman

text:
@EyeAmBatman¬†I see. Though I don't think these views are derived from 'fear' ..psychologically speaking it's more likely that there are other mechanisms at play..

And well, I am meticulous but I haven't applied that part of my nature to any replies.. I actually type quite fast. I used to work for the courts. I believe any perceived vehemence is just projection, but it's not impossible.¬†
Again, I am human.

But sticking to the initial idea of your comment, I would agree and disagree with you, but I will not elaborate. Not only do I have limited time, and after today, energy, but I suspect my 'musings' will go unappreciated haha.

Though at this point I struggle to remember my initial point, I still stand by it, as you accurately ascertained ( alliteration, whuut! ) , I have a meticulous nature and if there were any holes in my logic I would have already thought of them. I am a highly skilled debater, though I actually haven't used any of that skill here, then again it's hardly the crowd.

So, to conclude, many will disagree with me just on the merit that they do not 'like' me or think I am smug or some other derivative of that sentiment, but it's who I am. If I see flaws in logic and reasoning I React. , Almost, emotionally . ha ;)

+Demetri Aquilonian 
Since we  as a country have a democratic system, whomever gets the vote in this predominately 'two-party system is, at least theoretically, representative of the majority of persons who have cast their vote. Historically, there is a 'swinging' back and forth and a 'balancing' of power and ideas.' 

The person elected  President reflects the level of intelligence and wisdom of the populace, or lack thereof! (There are obviously  vested interests impacting the direction of our election.)  There is no perfect system of government. 

Fortunately the Internet provides a groundswell sharing of diverse information,  ideas and values communicated across the globe. text: +Silver Mirai Thats an interesting philosophy. I'm somewhat excited to actually know what happens when we die. It's a fascinating topic
author: Sam Majcher

text:
@Sam Majcher¬†I could talk about the subject for so long, I actually was very preoccupied with it. The hypothesis I came up with follows the logic of non-existence and coming into existence. Logically speaking, time has to have a beginning, otherwise we wouldn't reach this point, or the other possibility is that we could've always existed outside of time, but time also has to have a beginning for us to exist in any case. And in "us" I refer to our consciousness. So, we can only experience existence, so for us, existence is the only thing we know. So either we always existed outside of time and we cannot remember, or we came into existence, from non-existence.
In the case of non-existence and entering existence, it means there was a chance for this to happen, a combination of elements in the universe, multiverse, or whatever it might be. And by logic, if we do exit existence once our body is biologically "dead", there is the same chance of entering existence again, perhaps the only thing preventing us entering existence at any point is that we already exist so it doesn't make logical sense. And if this isn't the case, then it can be any other hypothesis in which we exist anyway.¬†

So, developing scenarios like this and deducting things about them by logic alone, I came up with a few possible cases. And in each case I actually am ok with them. Death now doesn't scare me as before I thought about these things. Mind you, I was actually depressed about my own mortality, now I am totally ok with it.¬†

I don't know if it has value or not for others, but for me it makes sense, and at least it gives me peace of mind and all that.

The reason I didn't wanted to go in detail is because it's allot to talk about, and I didn't even said everything I came up with, I thought about this for a long, long time, and I discussed this with my best friend, an engineer, and programmer, and he added a few things and confirmed the logic behind it. So, for me it has value.
author: Silver Mirai

text: @Silver Mirai That was actually really interesting to read. I'm still trying to figure out what I believe so finding out what everyone else thinks is fun. Thank you for sharing your thoughts my friend.
author: Sam Majcher

text: @Sam Majcher¬†No problem, I know how it feels to try to figure out what to believe about this subject, it can be unsettling, I try to give people pure logical reasons to be at peace.¬†
