text:
+Silver Mirai  "Logically speaking, time has to have a beginning"

to imply there is a "beginning" is to say that before such an event would exist nothing. this is self-contradicting. there is no reasonable ability to speculate, therefore it is unfalsifiable. time does not have to have a beginning, it is a relative perception. We can only experience an existence as much as we interact with such thing. An explanation of probability is not an explanation if everything is probable, proof is about identifying consistency. The only possible alternative is that this "existence" you experience is not the real "existence".

If logic is your thing I would recommend Kurt Godel's "Incompleteness theorem" and the concept of "falsifiability"
author: B L

author: B L

text: @Silver Mirai¬†within one second can be en eternity, therefore one must assume it is only one for the purpose of establishing a frame of reference.
author: B L

text:
The words beginning, present, and past are all arbritary words that describe daily life, but not living. You may have begun your life on your birthdate, or when you first snuck into your mom's egg. Time, however, is not that simple of a concept, time 'started' when we began counting it - there was no beginning of time, the same way we will never reach the end of time - because we only experience a small degree of it.  


Essentially, we aren't living in the 'present' we are just alive.

For example, i dont feel pity and sorrow and become sad and mellow for handicapped people (in wheelchairs for example), because i can read them - they hate it. I have respect for them, but pity - no. They continue with their life, in this or that way, and that is respectful.
With Sam it is different. Although i want to feel only respect and admiration, i feel sad... It's the fact that he will die soon (or he died). As you said - He is aware of it. And all people in comments bashing you simply cannot see full picture. His life time is predestined, and no matter what he does or how many drums he plays, it wont change it. People are 'programmed' to feel pity for a person who is one step in the grave. It's cruel to say, but there is no true happiness.
'He fights back a lot of tears.' :(
author: Stefan Jockovic

text:
@Stefan Jockovic¬†I feel like happiness is more like a reward that reinforces the proper orientation more than it is a state of being. ¬†When your mind and your body is committed to the virtues, I believe you feel touches of happiness. It is like a divine signal. ¬†

I think a lot of people mistake base pleasures for happiness. ¬†They are related but carnal pleasures can be had divorced of any virtuous endeavor. ¬†

Everyone has their cross to bear but I do believe some people carry heavier ones. ¬†Sam is strong, and the last thing I want to do is undermine that power that he exudes. ¬†However I think we both see his agony without which a meaningful life is not possible.

¬†
author: Leopard-King

text:
@excusia¬†Oh boy, guess i'll have to learn english more to completely understand your post. (at least first and second part)
Wait, you said in your last sentence that Sam actually had meaningful life? (through agony, which is inevitable). I hope he had, but only he knew that, so we will never know if his happiness really overthrown his agony which we both agree he felt.

text:
@The War Pug¬†The total amount of suffering per year in the natural world is beyond all decent contemplation. During the minute that it takes me to compose this sentence, thousands of animals are being eaten alive, many others are running for their lives, whimpering with fear, others are slowly being devoured from within by rasping parasites, thousands of all kinds are dying of starvation, thirst, and disease.

It must be so. If there ever is a time of plenty, this very fact will automatically lead to an increase in the population until the natural state of starvation and misery is restored. In a universe of electrons and selfish genes, blind physical forces and genetic replication, some people are going to get hurt, other people are going to get lucky, and you won't find any rhyme or reason in it, nor any justice. The universe that we observe has precisely the properties we should expect if there is, at bottom, no design, no purpose, no evil, no good, nothing but pitiless indifference.

text:
+Iris Ho 
Except you have no proof your version of reality is the true one. Your position is even counterintuitive. Humans have and always had the strong intuition that there are indeed morally good and wrong things. You say there is "no design, no purpose, no evil, no good, nothing but pitiless indifference". However you say that because you want to believe there is no life after death. So, in order to believe that, you despise your human intuition that there are morally good and wrong things (because there is indeed no such things without life after death). But I find it would be more rational to proceed conversely : We must first accept that, indeed, the fact that there are morally good and evil things seems more likely than the contrary. Then from that we can deduce that there is likely a life after death.

text: +Iris Ho Although your statements on this situation are downright cruel and bleak, I have to admit there is a little but of truth there. However, saying that he could't possibly have a good amount of wisdom because he's a teenager couldn't be more wrong. Never has age determined wisdom, it's experiences. If a ten year old kid went through an uncountable number of traumatic and unusual events and an 80 year old lived their entire life without really ever doing or thinking about anything, which do you think would have more wisdom? And if you're still certain that younger people can't really be that wise, then do some research into the childhood of the last Dalai Lama. If you STILL don't think that its possible at that point, then its you who is really in denial. (Also, as for you're perspective on life, if everyone focused on any/all of that, the world would only have more suffering in it).

text:
+Macie Jay Please, don't call people "ignorant" regarding a subject as elusive as happiness. No one knows (exactly) what happiness is. 
As to the neurochemicals you're talking about,  (oxytocin, endorphins, dopamine...), they are triggered by the daily choices you make (e.g. setting goals and achieving them). Thus, yes, even in a purely chemical point of view, Happiness is a choice.

text: @will jordan¬†Ah, the internet. ¬†Where you can make jokes you can't say in public, thanks to society. ¬†Honestly, if I see someone with a crappy JPEG minecraft profile picture, I don't assume much from them. ¬†Now, if you were referring to my comment about the jokes I made toward the kid in the video, that's another story...actually, no, it's the same thing. ¬†Thanks to the internet, I can makes jokes not socially acceptable in public...although not gonna lie, in today's society, making jokes about a kid isn't the worst that can happen.
author: TheDougieFresh

text: +TheDougieFresh You're kind of abusing the fact that the internet is anonymous.  Unless you normally do go around, jokingly, saying awful things to people in the real world.  Or, at least, when you make a crude comment without any clear indication of it being a joke you're risking hurting somebody's feelings or belittling another's struggle.
author: WateryIce54321

text: @WateryIce54321¬†Struggle? ¬†Please, I've gone to el Salvador many times, and if you give a homeless kid with missing fingers a pair of shoes, any kind, he gets emotional because he has to walk around an entire town with rocky roads to sell mangoes just so his family can buy some food from a gas station near their makeshift home out of leaves and branches. ¬†That's struggle. ¬†This kid in the video had the luxury of education, home to live under, and 3 meals a day. ¬†Hell, he's on TED for cutting a drum in half (which if you know anything about instruments, those things are made to a precise measurement, so he killed the tone), and you're saying he's struggling? ¬†His only struggle is that disability. ¬†
author: TheDougieFresh

text: +TheDougieFresh You must not be aware that you are mocking a dead man. He died shortly after this video came out. At age 17. He was a brave kid because many people who have disabilities like this become depressed because EVERYTHING is hard for them to do. He could barely walk, but he joined marching band. He weighed 50 LBS(which is about 150-170 lbs under the average 17-year old male weight) but still made a way to play snare. And, the drum he was playing wasn't cut in half, it was a small snare drum. The weight problem came from the harness, which can range from 30 pounds to 50 pounds( which is over half of his weight). I would know that, I am in marching band in my highschool. This kid is two times more of a man than you, because anyone who mocks someone so harshly over a physical and devastating disability isn't much of a man. You think that just cause there are people who are worse off than him that he isn't even brave. That makes no sense. Yes, there are starving kids who might have it just as bad (or worse) it doesn't mean that he doesn't struggle. And if you think that way even after reading this, then I bud you well, and hope that one day God touches your soul
author: Wrolnick 3

text: @Wrolnick 3¬†You want God to touch my soul? ¬†The same "God" that gave this kid E.T syndrome? ¬†Please. ¬†Come back to me when you stop the fake sympathy for this kid you don't even know. ¬†I've seen worst in places I've been. ¬†This? ¬†This is Autism to what I've seen, kid.
author: TheDougieFresh

text: @TheDougieFresh¬†Eh? ¬†Arguably, being given a definitive life span that is a 1/5'th of most humans and living with constant weakness is (at least) just as bad as living hungry for a period of time. ¬†Though, more importantly, my comment was not even specific to Sam. ¬†It's just... why make hateful remarks jokes or remarks in the first place? ¬†People will always appreciate your love and support over insensitive remarks.
author: WateryIce54321

text: +Matt That's pretty fucking obvious, Matt.  The internet's forums are a cesspool of anti-social outcasts, bully victims, and friendless losers who take out their anger on anyone from the safety of their bedroom.
author: Alpha male feminist

text: +TheDougieFresh You seem intelligent and make a few salient points about some of the advantages this kid (yeah he was only a kid) had being born into a Western country and having loving family and friends to support him - something I'm sure you have too. But where is your empathy? Sam's life must have been difficult at times. The world just isn't built for him. Yet here he was, bravely and eloquently speaking to the world about what his happiness philosophy was and how he thought he might be able to help, not because of his disability - but in spite of it. Get back to me when you make a similar contribution. Until then, think about what your comments do to the family and friends of Sam. They should be so proud of what Sam managed to achieve in his short life without having to read through cruel and ill informed 'jokes' by people hiding behind a screen.
author: BakedToPerfection1

text: @BakedToPerfection1¬†Contribution as in, working double shifts, only to not only pay for myself, but pay for my struggling family over in el salvador, not taking a sick day and working my ass off for tips, and a possible but small chance of getting a raise? ¬†Me being the only one to get a scholarship to a college because of Martial Arts. ¬†Yeah, my contributions don't mean anything except for my poor family back in El Salvador, with multiple members living in one house, yet they don't bitch about it. ¬†They accept it, try to find labor jobs for themselves and sell whatever fruit they have growing in their trees behind their house to people who will want them in the nearby city. ¬†But this guy has a disease, so it's much more inspirational, right? ¬†Like I said, despite having a disease as bad as this, he still lived a normal middle class american life, all the luxuries that an american has. ¬†He made a lighter shoulder carrier for marching band, but because he has said disease, he's getting all this praise. ¬†Doesn't seem to me like he knows the true meaning of suffering. ¬†
author: TheDougieFresh

text: +TheDougieFresh This offends me on a personal level. My little sister has struggled her whole life with disability. I've met so many people who aren't like you and me. But they have more heart than someone like you. They don't go around insulting people over things that are unchangeable. I know a ten year old boy who was born without legs, and with a learning disability. He plays wheelchair basketball and is one of the top students in his class. He overcame his problems. He was brave. Nothing can change that. No matter how much worse someone else has it.Like I said before, I hope God touches you. You're in my prayers dude. And, don't bother responding. You're just getting more hate for yourself bro.
author: Wrolnick 3

text: @Super Partes¬†3d world countries? ¬†oh boy, here I thought I was living on a two-dimensional plane. ¬†And yes, I did make jokes about this kid. ¬†Do I feel bad, that's up to you to decide. ¬†But nothing pisses me off more than Obligatory Empathy. ¬†And yes, society does force you to feel empathy towards someone with a disability. ¬†It's what we live on. ¬†But...here's the but...we only feel empathy to our own people. ¬†A great example is what happened in Rwanda. ¬†If you see the movie "Hotel Rwanda", you see exactly what I'm talking about. ¬†This one guy made a statement saying, "if they see what's going on here, they'd say 'oh, how terrible', and continue eating their dinner". ¬†That's what's going on here. ¬†Everyone here comments "how sad", "rip", "what a brave kid", etc. ¬†But do they think about doing anything to fix the problem? ¬†When they see a homeless man, do they actually give them money? ¬†Do they actually feel bad? ¬†That's what I'm talking about. ¬†It's human nature. ¬†
author: TheDougieFresh
TheDougieFresh

text:
@TheDougieFresh¬†You're far too uneducated to know how the "world works". ¬†It's far more complex than what you learned in Philosophy 101 at your community college.

Human behavior is virtually similar to all other living organisms. ¬†We behave in a way that helps us survive and reproduce. ¬†

When we share our resources, without the expectation of being rewarded, it's usually relatively small. ¬†You could say that feeling good is the major motivation for behaving altruistically, but that's hardly substantiated.

Your entire argument is based on a lot of assumptions and not a lot of data. ¬†So, I advise that you wait until you're a bit more educated in human behavior before you start condescending others with your "you're too young to understand" bullshit. ¬†Your pseudo-intelligence is pretty damn transparent.¬†
author: Alpha male feminist

text:
@Barrel¬†Hmm. ¬†Maybe I am un-educated. ¬†Maybe being born and raised in a 3rd world country to see suffering, and then coming to America seeing the huge difference has made me a little close minded about things. ¬†And no, I don't take Philosophy. ¬†It's just a belief that I've held onto ever since I heard about it back in Highschool, learned more about it, and realized how harsh and true it is. ¬†

"When we share our resources, without the expectation of being rewarded, it's usually relatively small. ¬†You could say that feeling good is the major motivation for behaving altruistically, but that's hardly substantiated." ¬†What do you think Religion benefits from? ¬†People commit good deeds because they don't want to burn for eternity or get reborn into a rat. ¬†No matter how you cut it, everything comes full circle to how the person committing the act feels, and what he gets out of it. ¬†If you can't see that, you're as close minded as an extremely biased person. ¬†

I work hard to get payed, why? ¬†To pay for a roof for me to live under. ¬†To have food for me to enjoy. ¬†To be able to support my family back home, because I no longer want them to suffer. ¬†

Explain why you go to school, and why you work, without using any form of "me", or without involving yourself in the explanation, and tell me how it goes. ¬†If you can do that, than I'll drop the entire subject, and drop an obligatory "what a brave kid, RIP, this made me cry" comment on this video like the rest of the crocodile teared people have.
author: TheDougieFresh

text:
@TheDougieFresh¬†Your question is really stupid. ¬†Now you're implying that just because we do most things for ourselves, that we must do all things for ourselves.

If people were truly selfish - why would anyone ever donate to charity? ¬†$50 is much more valuable than cuddly feelings. ¬†Why would people volunteer their lives in Africa?

Of course any explanation I give is going to have a me in it. ¬† Without me thinking about doing something, I wouldn't be able to do it.

The funny thing is I mostly agree with you. ¬†All animals are going to behave selfishly 99.9% of the time. ¬†The problem with you is you take it very cynical and twist words around. ¬†You seem to think that everyone is without compassion for others. ¬†I get it though - you're from a third world country, and usually poor people will slit each other's throats if there's a piece of fucking bread to win from it...but in more developed, wealthy countries, there's room for compassion and empathy.

This is not some fucking idea that some prehistoric dude came up with before praying to the rain God for some harvest...this is something that is shown through the study of animal behavior. ¬†It's not human nature, it's "animal nature".
author: Alpha male feminist

text:
+TheDougieFresh You seem very bothered and upset by people showing sympathy for someone who passed away after living with a physical disability, yet lived to be as happy as he possibly could. Maybe you just had lack of attention from your parents, serious neglect or a poor upbringing, and feel the need to take your frustration out through the comment section. If this is the case, I highly suggest therapeutic or medical help.... it seems like it would greatly benefit your butt-hurt ego. 
Otherwise, I would greatly appreciate it if you spent your time elsewhere and stopped appearing in my notifications. It hurts my brain while reading whatever your unstable state of mind is producing behind a keyboard. Make better use of your time instead of unleashing your inner anger through the comment section of a YouTube video, where realistically your opinion/rant is irrelevant and useless to the world. 


:)
author: Matt

text: @TheDougieFresh Just cause you have seen people in worse situations, doesn't mean you need to not feel for other men and women. Someone could just be depressed and I'd feel for them. Doesn't mean I've never seen true suffering, cause, honestly, you're right. There are people in unimaginable poverty, pain, and just overall bad places. Ive seen it. Ive been to island nations and I was nearly beaten for my money. Luckily, it never came to that, but it happened. Ive seen horrible pain, and so have you. Hell, ive seen a man die from typhus while on a mission trip. You probablt saw even WORSE. But that doesn't make other people's situations good or nothing to worry about. You might believe that all humans are selfish, but I don't think that's true. I think that if people have fought to defend their families, like in the 3rd world countries of the world, that they are thinking more about the well being of their family. And, I'm happy that you worked hard and moved to the States. And I find it honorable that you still send money to your family. You have seen suffering, but that doesn't mean that other people don't struggle. There is a saying that people have been using for a long time: " Pain is relative". If someone grew up impoverished, then they suffered. But if someone grew up with a life threatening disability in the States, then that is a huge thing for them. Just like I said before, just cause some people have it worse, doesn't mean that this isn't bad. And you might never change, your view point may stay narrow, but I hope I broadened your horizon. I'm not gonna respond to you anymore cause you're too stubborn to back down and I'm done messing with it. But I hope that you could visit a church some time, I think you could really use the experience. I'd love to talk to you in person some time so we could have a reasonable discussion, rather than contribute to a youtube flame war.

text:
@Harry Barker To be depressed by that fact defeats the purpose of his speech.

A key lesson to be learned from his speech is not to not feel depressed about what we have no control over, and death is the one thing that no-one has control over. It's the one thing that ends future dreams, and the one thing that every single person has to experience. 

So "Keep moving forward." 

Imagine if Sam knew that he was going to die by that date. Would he have given this speech? I doubt it. Not knowing when you will die is part of God's mercy on us, if you believe in God that is. Otherwise you won't be able to live a normal life.

text: Mikhayla Fairbanks sorry to hear about your cousin...maybe the other guy got attention after he died because he's kinda famous...and your cousin is a guy in high school who is not on TV. That does not mean that your cousin is not special or important or that his life was not meaningful. Your cousin is meaningful and did change the world in his own way for the better simply by being here. We all make a difference by being here. One of the good things he did was be friends with someone different. But of course there are plenty of other things he did that were positive. Like be a kind and loving cousin to you. I honor your sadness about your cousin passing away. Don't forget how happy your cousin made you, you can keep that memory with you always and carry it around with you to cheer you up on gloomy days. As you remember your cousin, you can play a song like You Were There by Babyface to celebrate your cousin being in your life and loving you. :) It's a song honoring a friend that Babyface had who died. He's so glad to have known this friend so it is a wonderful song dedicated to their beautiful friendship. :) Please listen to it and tell me what you think. :)

text: @Anastasiya Yes, even though I have just seen this incredible young man who has awesome character, it's really terrible to scroll down and see absolutely thoughtless cruel comments.  I know I should just feel sorry for folks who say terribly shameful things about a challenged human being like Sam  Berns.  You can tell that he had a lovely family, because you don't display the maturity and  life knowledge he expresses in his video if you make shameful comments.  What an incredible amount of joy he surely gave to his family.  It's been a long time since I've been brought to tears by seeing a person I never knew, just pour forth all this humanity, all from an incredibly bright sensitive young man.  Thank you to all the people who made this TED talk possible. I personally cannot imagine how anyone could criticize this person or his message. But it just has to be an individual who isn't from a loving family, so they will go through life not achieving near what Sam Berns achieved.

author: Lynnygreen

text: @*****¬†my take is that it shouldn't even be our decision to begin with. ¬†Maybe this quote explains it better then I can: ¬†"I think human consciousness is a tragic misstep in evolution. We became too self-aware. Nature created an aspect of nature separate from itself - we are creatures that should not exist by natural law... We are things that labor under the illusion of having a self, that accretion of sensory experience and feelings, programmed with total assurance that we are each somebody, when in fact everybody's nobody... I think the honorable thing for our species to do is to deny our programming. Stop reproducing, walk hand in hand into extinction - one last midnight, brothers and sisters opting out of a raw deal."

text:
+TheBcboy2 It's something everyone has thought to themselves I'm sure. If we take emotion out of the equation and just look at it purely objectively in a "how do we best preserve the species" approach then it's an interesting question.¬†


One thing that makes us stand out above all other animals is our ability of self-awareness. We are aware of not only the survival of ourselves but also of each other. Purely objectively I think the best course of action would be to preserve the life of everyone possible, unless preserving the life of one person would cause harm to others (in cases of murder, rape, etc) or destruction of our knowledge/technology. By preserving his life not only would he live, but we might also learn new things about Progeria and possibly advance our understanding about medicine as a whole.


The fact that we are even discussing how to best preserve our species survival is an even more impressive feat. Our ability to communicate with one another and transfer knowledge to each other makes us almost like a single mega-organism. At this point, we are the fittest.

text: @Sexual Potatoes Sam is an amazing person, truly, he has qualities way above those fake, plastic people who are worshiped today. Only people who are not blinded can understand this.

+Sexual Potatoes The people who leave mean comments for stories like this tend to be 1 of these 3 forms of douchebags.


1) The "contrarian". The sort of douchebag who doesn't have a real opinion on anything, but simple waits for a consensus to emerge so they can be on the opposite side of it and project "uniqueness". The types of people who always change their favorite movie/band/book, because they suspect their favorite movie/band/book is "becoming too popular". The same people who always make sure to "prefer" a director's more obscure, less mainstream films. Their fear is ever having to acknowledge they're average

2) Compensating for an inferiority complex Douches. The douchebags who like to think of themselves as the ones who see through the bullshit others cannot, whom desperately try to poke holes in something to discredit it if it means something to another. these sort of douchebags have a pavlovian response to tear down any offered inspirational story. In truth, they're simply bitter, unaccomplished people who want to strip anyone else of credit, joy.....this is what motivates them. 17 year-old staring death in the face and still finding meaning in life?-- ""Big whoop, he's simply saying basic motivational stuff anyone could say, he just gets attention because he's dying"" (overlooking the fact that depth has always been linked to context for any inspiring speech/talk...and his rapidly approaching death is most certainly a meaningful context to his words and wisdom). Their fear is that others will recognize not that they merely aren't average, but that they are, in fact, disappointments.

3) Pathological Liars. People so afraid of ever revealing a genuine human part of themselves to someone, that they take pretend positions that a genuine person would never take, or be able to understand. It's a way of being in a social realm, but still shielding yourself from the terror of anyone having to know the real pathetic you. By annoying and pissing people off, it makes them feel powerful, in control...makes the fact that they're genuinely cowards feel less emasculating. Basically the psychology of 99% of internet trolls. Their fear is that if they ever be themselves, that nobody would ever pay attention to them.

text:
Maybe i could speak for many of my dear trolls/nolifers/fat bastards/internazis comrades:

Good evening, ladies and gentlemen... and trolls.

As Dane Potmo pointed amazingly well in his douchebag classification, we're bound to be one of the aforementioned forms. In my case, i'm the combination of all the categories over 9000. I've achieved this hard task by mastering many of the trolling tools available... but mostly three of them. I'll call them the "tour de force of teh interwebz":

1) Doing it all for the lulz :our highest glory is to achieve a transubstantial state of LMAO-ROFL-TROLOLOL.
2) If it exists on the internet, it CAN and it MUST be shitted on : 10/10 i'll buy 100 kthx.  
3) Trolling is a vital part to sustain balance, along with the srs bsns : the cake is a lie... but what if it's true?

Our duty is to provide the rest of the world with a starting point to compare between good st0ff and bad st00000ff. Everybody likes the keyboard hero who posts a good comment about love, peace and how Jesus saved his family from anal cancer.

... Ok, the anal cancer picture won't show on the screen. Whatever, lets do go on...

How could you treasure teh interwebz good deeds, if there was no nutjob/shitprick/titfucking comments around? Thanks to our important labour, boosted by energy drinks, doritos and basement dwelling... we give enough reasons for everyone "normal" (Orly?) to believe they're doing the right things. And don't worry: we will endure the comebacks/exposures/bans. We've bled for it and we would die for it. Believe me, brothers. 

With his honest smile, a Cockmongler once told me, "There can't be light without darkness, nor virtue without goatses".

Let us be the goatses of the past, present and future. Release a strogre of hope and be brave.

Thank you and don't let the pizza be aggressive towards you.

text:
I personally believe that we don't have free will, neuroscientist Sam Harris has convinced me of that. So everyone who commits hatred and anger against others, and even the good people in our world, only did these things because of the conditions they grew up in. They were given a genetic DNA base, and then an environment to develop, and because of these things, they make the decisions they do. Everyone including you and me, the fact that I'm talking to you right now is because I love discussion and have a yearning for truth and a passion for life. If I didn't have all of these things, I would probably be doing something else right now, and that means that I didn't choose it. What makes us who we are is simply our choices our brains make due to our nature and the environment we lived through. If you want to see evidence for this, watch Sam Harris' video on free will, it's about 45 minutes long and he gives his logical case against it.

Now what this means is that nobody is at fault for their mistakes, nobody was the cause of their successes. The things that they did because of what happened to them is ultimately the only thing that made them who they are. We kind of go through everyday life assuming this isn't true just for simplicity's sake; but we should be very careful to understand that this isn't at all ACTUALLY true. If you had been born as Ted Bundy, had the same exact childhood, the same life experiences as he did, and the same things happened to you, you would have done the same exact things, including those horrific murders. You would have BEEN Ted Bundy.

So I do not believe in punishment solely for the sake of punishment, never will I believe in that as long as I reject the idea of free will as most people conceive it.

Keep that in mind if you truly are thinking about committing murders, sure it may feel justified, but all you are doing is selfishly taking your own rage against society out on innocent people, who may or may not be ignorant evil people, but even if they were, death solely for punishment isn't just. So if you are at all a moral person, you would understand what you yourself said, "You can't fight fire with fire."
author: ghostsade3

text:
@Peter Grimstad
And if you understand there is no such thing as free will, you will never again have a reason to hate yourself for doing something wrong, or failing a specific task, even for the dozenth time. For how can one succeed without first failing? It only becomes a tragedy when you give up, and even then you can always come back. The goal is to make the world a little bit better than it was before you came into it, to improve the conditions of life for everyone around you. If everybody did that, the world would be an amazing, glorious place.

text:
@ghostsade3¬†I definitively understand that there is no free will. Therefore, you don't make any choices. That's why I hate god. For giving me such a awful life.

I know, nobody is at fault for their mistakes. STILL we punish people. I actually thought of it today, how wrong it is to punish other people for what they do. People are animals. Would you punish a dog for barking? No, I thought so. What we should do, is help people live with their disadvantages without bothering others. But then I have a question. How about the ones that never understands? Shall we just let them run around and keep doing wrong (I know there is nothing that is wrong and nothing that is right tho) things all their life? OR... should we kill them?
I don't find death a bad thing. If it were, then why do millions of animals, and thousands of humans, die each day? Nobody could make a as awful place as that.
If we made a way to kill humans that don't hurt, then why not?

And by the way, I guess I am the only human that is saying this, but if I am one of those people that don't fit, you are free to kill me.

text:
@Peter Grimstad It's good that you understand that free will is an illusion. But I must ask you, why do you believe in a god? And what god specifically? What are the qualities of this god? I do not believe in gods, so I have to ask you why you do, as I believe them to be fairy tales humans made up because humans NEED an answer to a question ("How did we get here?", "Why are we here?". "Who are we here for?". "Who/what made us?").

Because I don't believe in a god, it's impossible for me to blame a deity for my bad situation in life (though personally I tend to be optimistic, much healthier and true also, I am very lucky to be born a white male in North America in the 21st century in an economically free state in the U.S. specifically. How luckier can you get? You seem to be smart also, so that is also a lucky thing that happened to you and me. We happened to be smart. You should be happy that these things happened to you! But don't take pride in them as of course, you didn't cause them, even if free will was true, which it isn't. Optimism is the way to go in life, in my opinion. It's just so much happier and healthier that way, to not take things for granted and to find happiness from simply existing (mindfulness meditation helps immensely here), not from worrying about what qualities you have or what judgments people make of you or what you make of yourself. Just from feeling, existing, breathing. That is what mindfulness meditation SHOWS you, although it can be tricky to do it at first if you've never tried it before, but it is an amazing, secular, tool.

What we do with the people who just don't understand empathy and society's rules is that we prevent them from rampantly breaking those rules by imprisoning them. I personally don't believe the government is necessary for this, there can be private courts (ala Judge Judy, an arbitrator; and more serious courts than that if need be) without the government intruding on our lives with force to imprison these cocksuckers. Sure, they aren't to blame, but they CANNOT be allowed to roam freely doing as they please, obviously. So the clearest, easiest, cheapest answer is to lock them up. But it must be for actual crimes, not victimless ones like any drug offense, here in America we lock up FAR, FAR too many people we have 5% of the world's population and 25% of the world's PRISON population, our prisons are so overflowing that people have to wait days or weeks even just to get into the general living area of inmates where they all sleep on bunkbeds lined up in rows in a huge room. So OBVIOUSLY, our prison system needs to change. But, of course, we will still imprison the people that NEED to be imprisoned.

Death actually is a "bad" thing if you believe that there are desirable and undesirable outcomes. I believe that because we are all basically computers, we COULD live amorally. But such a life would be very risky, and evolution proved this to be true because humans are naturally altruistic; that is, they are good people, they help others! Not necessarily "naturally" in the sense that it is genetically imprinted in all of us, but society has developed in such a way that it is taught almost universally, so most people do develop altruism. And humans are natural and we haven't broken out of our evolutionary heritage so it must be natural to be altruistic. But the same man (Sam Harris) who convinced me that free will is an illusion also convinced me that science can at least partially determine human morality because we know what inputs to put into a human system that will produce happiness and pleasure. But he says there are many peaks and many valleys of human happiness and suffering and he calls this the moral landscape. Look up "Sam harris moral landscape" if you want to know more about that. But I believe death is UNDESIRABLE as life exists solely to reproduce, so why would it be desirable to end that cycle?

The reason the world is so fucked up today especially compared to certain times in the past is mostly, I believe, due to states, a.k.a. governments, around the world fucking up hard in the last several decades.

Sorry for the massive-ass book. I don't blame you if you don't read it all.
author: ghostsade3

text:
@ghostsade3¬†Thank you for replying! I thought you wouldn't answer at all, and I wouldn't blame you if you didn't. I would blame god! ;D

So... god. What is god? Well... you will probably think that I am crazy for saying this... but let me warm up with saying that I think having positive beliefs can be good as long as they don't go against science. With positive, I mean beliefs that can motivate you, or in any other way help you, not like the beliefs of I.S. and such.

And I have my own religion!
It is very simple. Or it could be very complicated. I can sum it up with one word: Infinity. I believe in infinity.
The simplest way to understand infinity, is to say ... one. Everything is one. Everything else, is just infinity... being infinite. Now, believing in infinity means believing that everything have happened, will happen and happens right now. This means that yes, indeed, there might actually be a god up there. Or twenty. Or a million. I have no idea. But I know that infinity is the one "god" everything comes from. Because of this, I know that I am god, I am infinity itself, and I created this life I am currently living.

And to go a little deeper: Let's say we have this oneness. Now, out of this oneness comes new worlds, new layers of existence, that is all based upon the oneness, or infinity. When we die, how do we know if we will return back to this oneness, or just go to another layer, just a little closer to the oneness? Of course, at one point we will come back to that oneness, since... infinity, right? :)¬†Oh god, I am getting crazy of this :D We aren't supposed to understand this, that's the crazy part of it. And we can't know what I said now, maybe not even when we are dead.
Oh wow, I write a lot too.
I have so much so say about this... another funny thing with it, the individuality you feel. Like, you and I are two individual persons, right? FALSE! We are the same fucking thing. You get it? We are everything. And to drag souls into this too, you aren't the human. You are the soul riding the fucking human. We are all human-riding souls. But at the same time, we are all the atoms that build up everything around and within us. This is infinity. We are the playground, and we play with it.

So... yeah. That's my definition of god. One. God is one. But in the same time, god is ... a million. A billion. There is no limits. God is everything. God is hate, god is love.

Fuck, this is my fucking inspiration.. I can't stop to write about this.

But believe me, if this goes against science one day, I will throw it away. I'm not stupid enough to stay in my bubble when the surroundings change.

Dude, I have just one more thing to mention. This one is actually crazy, and I don't know what to think. I'm not crazy, I'm not going to actually believe in this before it makes enough sense. I had math. I did 1*1 and got 1. While when I did 2*1 I got 2. And 2*2 and got four. And 1*1*1 equals 1 too. You get it? Infinity * infinity doesn't work. That's why 1 is a "magical" number. 1 is everywhere. We just don't get it. 1*1*1*1*1*1*1 is 1 too! You see how strange it is? You could have ... infinite 1's, and it would still be 1.
Math is like the rules in this world, math is the rules everything goes by. And 1 is a part of this math. It is just that this 1, is the infinity of math. If you get it. What everything comes from.
I don't know what to make of the fact you can get 2 by doing 1+1. Maybe, since 1 is everything, you can't "+" 1 with anything else, since there is nothing else to "+" with.

You must think I am crazy. But I have been thinking about this for a while... and yeah. This is my religion.
Everything is possible! :)

text:
damn ... I didn't know about him until today when this video somehow popped up in my suggested videos. To be honest, after watching the video I was thinking. I don't really feel sorry for him, or particularly overjoyed that he has found happiness. Just more or less seemed like a regular kid. I mean of course he has this rare disease but he's smart, he's logical, he has actually done more that most people would ever hope to. So ... no reason to feel sorry for him. I was even being bold enough to think that in some ways ... he's lucky. Very very lucky indeed. I know it's weird to say that. But it is true at some levels.


That all being said. Your comment made me google it and yeah he's dead. Damn. I feel quite sad now. Which is interesting, I'm sad for someone I didn't know even existed 15 minutes ago. May indeed he rest in peace.

text:
@Loui Furgasson¬†It was just my personal opinion. But in any case, "lucky" is a subjective term. Your definition might differ with mine. So it's pointless to debate over it.¬†

Also, in my comment I specifically mentioned "in some ways, he's lucky". And I will stick with my statement. Everyone is lucky in some ways and unlucky in others. It's just how it works.

One of my best friends died a few years back when he was 20. He didn't "reproduce" as well. He didn't get to achieve the goals that he was more than capable of achieving. I still remember him of course. His parents remember him. His brother remembers him. At most a 100 people remember him ? 500 ? I would still say the same thing about him. He was unlucky that he died so young. And it saddens me immensely that he did. But doesn't mean he wasn't lucky in some other ways.

Now compare that with this kid. Because of his rare disease he got the chance to experience so so much. And now that he's dead, surely it's tragic and all but millions of people are sad for him. He's immortal on the internet. We're still having this debate about him months after he passed away. So yes, I believe he is also lucky in more ways than one.

Anyways, Cheers.

text: @***** That's an extremely biased comment'cha got there. I wonder if this is how most people with religious affiliation perceive atheists. If so, then my capacity of faith for mankind has plunged even further than it already has. Seriously, how heartless do you theists believe we are? Because apparently a particular majority of you people seem to view us as inhumane, inconsiderate, and persistent. Little did you know that we have healthy amounts of sympathy. HEALTHY AMOUNTS. I admire Sam Berns's personality, his fortitude, his intellect. And if you think for a split second that the first thing that came to mind when I discovered that he had died a month later was him in a fertilizer pit, congratulations, sir. Your ignorance level has skyrocketed past comprehensible limits. The essential belief of an atheist is the lack of a universal being. I WONDER HOW THIS BELIEF EQUATES TO ATHEISTS BEING INHUMANE, INCONSIDERATE, AND PERSISTENT. I've gone to a Catholic middle school and I attended freshman year at a Catholic high school so I can somewhat guarantee that I know Catholicism. I've read Leviticus, it's crazy I know; I've read bits and pieces of the Gospel, we had to, for it was commonly referred to in my homework. I stopped being a theist because I hate dependence on others; I didn't get the idea of a universal being, it didn't click with me; I hated the idea of wasting my time on prayers that have no guaranteed benefit  because I'd rather make a difference right now with my own two PHUCK'IN hands, you get me? Sure some atheists are rotten apples, but are you telling me that all theists are good red apples? I want you to read through the first 30 or so comments in the comment section, and I want you to find me one comment by an obvious atheist that harbored malicious intent toward Sam Berns's. There are none! They only look bad because of the radical atheist and theist replies to them. For instance, a religious comment may receive a negative atheistic reply, vice versa. Thank you for reading my long ass reply!

author: Otto the Smartass

text:
@Smartass (AKA Otto the Great)¬†"Except I'm the one in the right here while you're not." lol. 'kay.

"Can I ask you something, what if white people's voices matter more than black people according to modern society? ¬†How would you feel?"

I feel very sad about it. I also know that it's irrelevant to this discussion. This is about racial inequality and how the word of some people are ignored.

A better example would be saying that black people are a better authority than white people on what racial inequality feels like. That statement is true.

In a similar manner, a person with such a severe disability is a better authority than you and me on how to deal with severe hardship, because, you know, he has dealt with it. His word is not more valuable solely because he is disabled, it is of more value because it comes from experience. An able-bodied, or generally fortunate person does not experience life the way he does, so when they say stuff about overcoming challenges, it's easy to dismiss their word because they haven't ever faced any significant challenge in their life.

This is not a matter of inequality in listening to what people say, this is about giving different weight to the words of people with different experiences. Which makes sense.

text:
@illusion466 I think the message of the video is "everybody should be happy".... forget the "THIS GUY" part of it. The point is that rather than feeling sorry for ourselves or complaining about our lives or wasting energy on all that sadness, we should be able to find ways to be happy no matter our circumstances. If you live in poverty, be happy. You have your limbs amputated, be happy. Your girlfriend breaks up with you, be happy. You lost your favorite video game, be happy. It doesn't matter WHY you feel like you should be sad. The point is you don't need to. Forget about everybody else's life. 


His philosophy wasn't making comparisons of other people's lives to his own. His philosophy was about everybody finding happiness in their own circumstances.

Spread love, people, that's all this dying (and now dead) kid wanted to say. Be happy and look on the bright side of things. Depression can be beat one step at a time. author: Yetoo

text:
Haha, easy when every day is an immense struggle for him? Just sitting on that stage and talking caused a ton of strain for him. If you've got a working body, with none of the debilitating issues that this young man had, then the only thing holding you back from being happy is you. Your outlook is overtly cynical, as I have no idea how seeing the life this kid lead was "fortunate". His spotlight came from a disease, which meant for all those that might give him attention, there were others who would avert their eyes like he was a leper, or treat him with what they'd deem polite pity. He had no chance at a normal life and died right at the cusp of adulthood, having not experienced anything at all similar or with the passing fortune so many of us take for granted. Hell, I remember fucking up my knee in wrestling back in high school. Everyone treated me differently when I had a wheel chair and crutches. It was pity and it drove me insane, but that was only for 4 months of my life, this young man had to deal with it from day 1. Progeria meant that Sam and others like him new their clocks were only a quarter spun, so making the most of their situation is really all they can do. If someone honestly feels like a debilitating disease would better their lives, then not only are the sick in the head, but they're pathetic as well.

What's stopping you from doing what you're passionate about? Do you have anything similar to this kid? Are you disabled in some way? You obviously have spare time or you wouldn't be on here looking up videos. So instead of buggering all your time on videos and cynical comments, do what you're passionate about. Write, read, run, lift, dance, draw, paint, sing, learn something, etc etc. Just do it for christ's sake. You want life advice? Keep pushing forward, because there's no turning back and the pause button doesn't work. We all have tough times, but it is how you handle yourself and what you do, regardless of whatever bullshit excuse you might come up with to say otherwise. The only thing stopping you is you. You don't need money to be happy, you don't need tons of friends to be happy, you just need whatever it is that makes you happy or smile or feel content and embrace it.¬†
author: TheRadBroSexual

text:
@Miccollo
This is the egocentric philosophy that is making things hard or impossible for others. It's damn easy to say "It's all your choice" and then not care.
You know, there are people who have a long life and still didn't experience many of the things that Sam Berns didn't, even some that he did. Because, in case you haven't noticed, there are other people in the world, and dependencies, and people wanting to screw you over and exploit you when you give your best effort. Sam on the other hand led a happy life; he's got an awesome supportive family and general social environment, which is often key. As if only physical disability can turn life into hell, as if there weren't any other situations. So narrow-minded.
There's a reason why there's so much depression and suicide in the world, and the solution is not to self-servingly drop a popculture life-advice line and then call it a day.
https://twitter.com/Dowlphin/status/572195437047914496
There is a debilitating disease, and it's called lack of empathy (or mental convenience), and it makes life hell for others while benefitting the host.
author: Dowlphwin

text:
@D·¥è·¥° ü·¥ò ú…™…¥
Twisting my words and making more excuses. I never said only people with disabilities can have a life that's hell, I'm living proof of that. However, I didn't let cowardice and crying about my problems overwhelm me, as you have. I have empathy for those going through rough times, as I have been to hell and back time and time again, but I do not have patience for quitters like yourself. Your whole main statement was that you can't do what you want, then saying Sam somehow had an upper hand due to his illness.

News flash, there's always someone worse off than you, so learning to be grateful for what you have even if it's just health, is paramount. You can shrug off what I'm saying and continue to make excuses for yourself, but that's on you, just as being happy and doing what you love is on you. You have choices, but you limit yourself by telling yourself you can't or something else is stopping you. This isn't some bullshit pep talk, this is a person who's gone through mental, physical, and emotional torture from childhood to early adulthood imparting what they know.¬†

Whether you continue to wallow in your own pity or step up and do something is your choice. As it always has been.¬†
author: TheRadBroSexual

text:
@Miccollo
You have succumbed to your misery by becoming the problem, by claiming those who didn't manage to succeed are inferior, by blaming victims. THAT'S the easy way. Continue doing that and you might give people incentive to show you convincingly how there are things that can stop you.
I'm pissed because I won't abandon my empathy in order to stop the pain. Happiness isn't always good. It can also be a state of denial about the suffering of others.
The pain you refuse to experience is the pain you offload onto others.
The real heroes are not those who give coldhearted advice, but those who make a difference in other people's lives and are willing to be vulnerable.

text:
@Miccollo
I am not twisting your words; I know very well what I'm saying.
You are being a preacher for sickness. Inferior to what? To the hardships created through lack of empathy, to the pain people cause because they don't want to see their own anymore. A world full of sociopaths who can't understand the interconnectedness of experiences in society. You think you are doing good, but your actions are based on pain and separation, thus while you might believe yourself a helper, you are furthering the problems you think you are working on. The attitude is being radiated and shapes action. Your words are very much the stuff that drives people into suicide, when they realize how everybody seems to be out for their own benefit only, lying to themselves and others, cold-hearted.
So based on your lingo, I could say you are inferior because you are not aware of the pain that takes control of you. You lack social intelligence. You are a creature of the past, of the age that now needs to come to an end, where millions of people are dying because of this and related mindsets.
author: Dowlphwin

text:
@Miccollo
You keep sending more of what I pointed out. The popular idea of "natural order" doesn't allow for emotion or spirit, it treats humans like machines, thus machines it will create. A heart cannot be mended with rationality. You were in emotional pain and then it got painted over with another story in order to avoid healing. Healing happens through love, which you obviously and by your own account didn't receive, so that's why you keep sending out such a disgusting vibe that only makes things worse.
Having been tolerant and hopeful with people like you is one thing that burned me out, so now I'll just give people what they have coming.
You cannot expect empathy for your situation since you signal so clearly that you closed yourself to it. This is a polarity of epic proportions that plagues all of humankind and is why people still fight aggressive wars while believing they are righteous. It's all personal pain-avoidance by people who closed themselves off from being vulnerable. A sick mind telling itself yet another story that is better-adapted to the sickness around them. Thus more war, more death, more suffering, more suicides. It's a hydra. You chop off a head, believing yourself triumphant and successful, but two more will grow. It's the damn self-serving and convenient rationalization of: "What I do is right and good, and if it doesn't help someone, that means it's their fault."
You are exploiting people in distress in order to get validation for the bullshit you are telling yourself. Fiddling with symptoms to avoid looking at the root causes, which YOU will NOT be able to fix.

text: @D·¥è·¥° ü·¥ò ú…™…¥ Ok, I read all of the replies and posts you've made on this page. I'm going to start by analyzing some of the things you just said. I'll even use and extend your metaphors. First off, how can you say i "experienced trying to get somewhere with a sailing ship during a heavy storm, but never experienced the same with no wind at all." lets talk about this. First off, you say i had a "sailing ship" I can say a few things to this, first, How do you think i got a sailing ship? I built it, i worked hard. Or, another way to look at it,  i did what i had to do to make it aboard that sailing ship. How do you know i've never experienced the same with no wind at all? Trust me there were plenty of times there was no wind at all. You know what i did? Jumped off the boat and swim, pull out the paddles and start rowing through the storms if you have no wind. The point is this, if you want something bad enough you go get it. I had plenty of things happen to me that i could have sat around crying to the world about how fucked up my life is and go justify stealing and robbing and selling drugs, and everything else. I didn't do that, even though i had the excuse. I faced my challenges, some of the people in this thread are speaking from experience, we're not just making this shit up, we lived through hardships, and made it through. I come now and then to watch videos like this to remind myself that there are people out there that have had other big challenges. The challenges i faced were of extreme poverty, homelessness, and family problems. But i see people like the kid in this video and it reminds me that i had good health (relatively). Many people read or hear about my story and they tell me its very inspirational. I dont find it that way, but when i see someone with a physical disability and they are still able to do the same things as full able body people, that to me is strength and inspirational. I dont know what hardships you might be facing, but half of your post have one philosophy about helping people, and another is "why care about people who dont care about you" you talked about being cold-hearted, and these things in earlier post and that was a cold hearted thing to say, thats something I would say. Yes i can be cold hearted at times, and some of the other things you mentioned in earlier post. I'm not saying that having hardships makes you a better person, but it does create a type of strength. There are many different types of strengths. Some people find strength in helping others, and some find it in taking advantage of others. My philosophy is do what ever gives you strength, weather its good for you or for everyone, that doesn't matter. Do what gives you strength, period. I find strength in being selfish, but i've embraced who i am. I've joined two community service projects full time. I dont get paid, i just give a living stipend, its called americorp. I did that to try and understand what its like to not be so selfish and to give back and i know its very draining to care about people more than they care about themselves. When people take advantage of kindness it can be really discouraging. I was working last year with students as a mentor. It was very draining.  I am however grateful  for people like you, who do help other people, the world and people like me need people like you. There is a balance to the world, there are people like me, and people like you, its what makes the world great. Furthermore, I never saw the movie slumdog millionaire, and have no desire to. However, you say "Well, give me the script and I can make a few tiny tweaks to it and he will fail miserably." how about this, how about you take the script of YOUR life, make a few tiny tweaks to it and succeed tremendously. and i dont know, maybe you have, and if you are happy, and you do live the dream you've always had, then share it, be positive and dont spread these ideas that you've done in these replies. Honestly, one day you'll figure it out you seem very intelligent.
author: tj1990

text:
@tj1990
Focusing on whatever makes me strong took a while to cultivate. I actually had and still have to find a personally healthier mix of empathy vs. egotism. The strength of character and virtue I developed make things more difficult for me. Certain avenues are not an option, because I am also sensitive, and some stuff that others do casually and in convenient ignorance would hurt me if I did them in pursuit of my career.
There are also very old patterns in the mix that can be extremely difficult to overcome even with the ideal means available.
I had to literally become one with God just to lay the groundwork for making a small step forward years later, that I intended to work with then and which turns out opens up yet another can of opposing forces and problems. I guess you could call that making tweaks in my script, but then again, probably not according to how I used the metaphor, because I was changing myself and not the events I face. I have worked on myself and changed myself diligently, and have realized that the saying "Change yourself and the world around you will change" is pseudo-spiritual popculture life-advice, designed to comfort the speaker, not the receiver. The real wisdom and life skill¬† is usually much grittier and more unsettling.
Anger has served me better than positive thinking, so there's an example of potentially unsettling life truths. But I can handle it. It's usually others who can't. The always-think-positive crowd. It's emotional jerking-off.
Especially in that context, this wisdom-filled link comes to mind: http://eqi.org/invalid.htm It should be a mandatory read for everybody.
author: Dowlphwin

text: @D·¥è·¥° ü·¥ò ú…™…¥¬†I understand now. Thanks for the enlightening posts, i think many people dont fully understand what you're trying to explain. There are good points to be made on both sides. You've made good points, and so have some others. Most of these posts are mature as well. So this was good. The link helps a lot. I can see how you might think that motivational speakers don't often evaluate the feelings of the individuals they're speaking to. There is an insensitivity i can agree in some cases. Other people aren't as strong or willed as they may have been, and because they had the willpower to do something, they think everyone should/could have the same level of motivation, drive and determination as them, without evaluating their feelings which maybe preventing them from having that same will power or motivation. I think thats what you've been kinda talking about in these posts. ¬† ¬†
author: tj1990

text:
@tj1990
Yes, that's one of several interesting angles. The one who went through hardships shows that they have truly overcome them and become stronger if they don't try to apply their experience to everybody else's. When they do, it might be because they feel they need it, they need to believe that it was all just their own doing and making the right choices. The alternative would threaten the confidence-boost that the success-experiences have given, and this then shows that there is still a fear at work, a fear of losing that helpful belief. Some people become outright mean and arrogant because of that, getting corrupted by a survival-of-the-fittest mindset.

We have so many people in distress who seek out self-empowerment advice because the world is being shaped significantly by the same belief system that raises the self on a pedestal. But if people made the profound internal step of empowering the common, of helping each other, then the world would create less of that distress. Ego is about separation from the whole, so it is inherently fear-based. That fear needs to be kept in check in order to create a healthier and more pleasant world. And it is not about eliminating separation. It is one half of life experience. But balance is health, and the amount of suffering in the world shows that there is a severe imbalance. It causes the symptoms that signal a need for change. Signals that too few (want to) recognize and understand.
The problem is also that when you keep feeding a world of separation by teaching enough people the gospel of self-empowerment, further increasing an imbalance in the whole system, they will have to compete against each other. It is a vicious circle; a belief system that provides its own growing validation. A zero-sum game in a world that needs new to be brought into it.

I can be at my best when working with people who work on their fears. But when surrounded by people who are willing slaves to them, it can feel like torture, a nightmare, soulcrushing meaninglessness. One of the most empathic people I have ever met once accurately remarked that I am spiritually malnourished.
It has been a problem since early childhood.
author: Dowlphwin
gtheskater

text:
@gtheskater
Thank you. I have always been curious about all kinds of things and pondered deeply. I don't have a university degree, but I probably have comparable qualifications in some areas... likely with unusually high common sense for such fields, haha.
And yes, of course facing so many problems, too, makes one interested in understanding what the hell is going wrong.
Things don't really 'flow' for me at all, so I constantly get discouraged from pursuing various endeavors. Attending a university might open certain doors (then again, wouldn't be anything new if totally not), but it's a huge investment for realistically very little. It would depress me.
I also don't think pursuing the educational/intellectual path would be worth it, since the problem doesn't lie with lack of information, but with lack of interest in seeking it out. So I prefer the creative-artistic path, which feels more fulfilling, but has its downsides, too.
Basically, all I can do is be myself and not torture myself too much about not achieving what I want. I've tried so many approaches. But at some point, if the environment doesn't 'click', it's all just plans and wishes.
I also don't form a goal about changing the world, especially not an absolute one. I just want to be the best of myself and fully cultivate and express that. That's the best way to contribute to a better world.

I absolutely do have the potential to achieve great things, given the right opportunities. I easily jump on seeming opportunities and they turn out to be mere fakes, setups for a fresh batch of pain, and I don't want to accumulate even more of such experiences.
author: Dowlphwin

text:
@D·¥è·¥° ü·¥ò ú…™…¥ You've by far blew my mind, and that can be a difficult thing to do. You're right though in many aspects. You said "Some people become outright mean and arrogant because of that, getting corrupted by a survival-of-the-fittest mindset." This is me all the way. I find it very difficult to form relationships, im always fighting and arguing with people. I've become quite successful so i throw it into peoples faces, i put people down making myself feel better doing so. I do it all just to give contrast to the things that i've done. Its really bad. I've been fired from a lot of jobs because i cant form relationships or work well in teams. Overall, while i've been able to be "successful" in terms of having a career, and money, and being happy in some areas, its a false sense of happiness. Its a happiness derived from putting others down or keeping them down, so that i can stay at the top. My last boss described it as "a heart of war" i always think someone is trying to take advantage of me, take something from me, steal from me, i dont trust anyone at all, and im always looking for a fight. I just lie to myself telling myself that im ok being alone, because most people dont want to be around me.  i understand why i am the way i am. Think of it like a dog, that was abused its whole life, do you think that dog will turn out to be a very nice dog? no, its going to jump up and steal the food right out your hand, because that dog doesn't know the next time its going to eat. Sometimes i struggle with how i've become, other times i embrace it.


 Right now I'm an IT Apprentice and this is working out pretty well. I also agree that going to a university is usually not worth it. I think internship/apprenticeship style programs are much better, and worth it. You learn, and get job experience, and get paid. While a university is almost the opposite.
author: tj1990

text:
@tj1990
Then you understand how difficult it is to shed such mindset. After all, in a difficult environment, it has served you; it was or at least appeared to be necessary.
It is not ideal to close the heart, but when we do, it means there's a reason why we did, and that is always valid. The problems that have such effects on people can only be solved when we don't play the blame game.
For someone with a 'heart of war' though, you are quite unconfrontational in writing here. Especially these days, I usually see very quickly whether someone treats a discussion like a fight to be won or an opportunity for mutual enlightenment, and the result here is solid evidence that you're not that deep into trouble; a good sign.
A practice that might help you is this: Allow yourself to be vulnerable. I know very well from own experience and am struggling with it myself: We succeed not when we trust that things will turn out alright (that's the popculture wisdom which can lead to horrible wounds), but when we expect that things might fail and can handle it and go on regardless. Or remember Rocky Balboa: It's not about how hard you can hit, but how hard you can get hit, and get up again. Interestingly, from what you wrote before one would think you are excellent at that, but of course you have your limit, too. You are shielding your heart from further hurt. That you are aware of the problem with that is good. It means you know what you have to do; gradually, step by step.
I don't know whether you are familiar with brony stuff, but in My Little Pony, Fluttershy is like a shining example of this: She is very sensitive and vulnerable, and she has that impressive ability of not closing her heart in painful situations, but allowing herself to hurt fully (thus embracing her true nature), and in that way gets over it quickly and without scars, and that is strength through weakness. (Profound wisdom so often seems contradictory, because the mind cannot comprehend the heart.) But: This also depends on whether the environment allows her to live that way, to find that strength. And that's where the magic of friendship comes into play.

Recently, during a ceremony where I connected with a wiser version of myself, I reminded myself to always express my feelings and worries openly, that it can only enrich my life. It is a teaching of overcoming fear. And that's what the game of life is about.
Another allegory: Do you know Avatar - The Last Airbender? Zuko fueled his firebending with rage. At some point, he resolved his anger issues and then realized he couldn't firebend anymore and that that had been the source of energy, so he now had to find a healthy source to fuel his ability again, which he had thought was the essence of wrath. Maybe that's a bit like the challenge you are now facing - a motivational transition. It can be scary. I remember someone telling me she had become a successful lawyer, and at some point she resolved a bunch of emotional issues with her family and in the process realized that all her career success was due to her unhealthy desire to please her parents. She no longer felt a desire for that career path and changed her life. Of course it's not easy, but acting based on a healthier version of yourself is good. ... Then again... as I know so very well ... it can also make things more difficult.
author: Dowlphwin
Isaac Lowe

text: @Isaac Lowe¬†But hapiness also must come for a reason. A life filled with pain has no reason for it to be felt with happiness. Commonly when you can overcome those bad circumstances that cause you pain then you are able to feel happiness, but we can't just make joy out of thin air when we live a painful life by choices or causes that weren't ours. That's what Dowlphin tried to say before in a comment somewhere up there... It is good indeed to feel happy when the pain is visible and we grabbed it and punched it in the face. But when your life is full of an empty and invisible war... You are driven to an attitude of futile resistance. I too can feel it for example when I have a walk outside. People, nature, physics, they are all around and right in front of us. All the pain, the desire, comes from those simple things right in front of my eyes, yet I can't overcome many things that make me cry because I shall never understand them.
author: gtheskater

text: @gtheskater‚Äã i don't know, i guess that's an interesting philosophy. We can be happy if we can grasp the thing that would otherwise be making us miserable, but when we can't pinpoint the source of our unhappiness, it's more difficult to overcome, is that what you're saying? I suppose i could agree with that, but i wouldn't go so far as to say that it's impossible to find happiness in bleak situations. I think it's all about the attitude. Me personally, God and my religion are a major source of happiness even at times that i feel nothing earthly can help me. I'm sure there are other ways of feeling happiness as well. I think that the only time our happiness can truly be gone is when we tell ourselves that there is no longer hope. I truly believe that happiness is a choice we can all make no matter the circumstances and no matter our understanding of the world. And maybe all we can start with is hope, in that case. We might not understand certain things, but that doesn't destroy hope. In fact, i think that having less understanding provides MORE room for hope. Maybe i misunderstood your comment, if i did i'm sorry.
author: Isaac Lowe

text: @gtheskater‚Äã basically i'm saying that if happiness really must come for a reason, then hope can be a reason if there's nothing else. I think it's true that there must be a reason to feel happiness, but that reason doesn't have to come from something outside of yourself. Or in other words, from in the world. The reason can come from inside yourself, no matter what the world around you might look like. Hope is a good example of that.
author: Isaac Lowe

text:
@Isaac Lowe
Many times I was driven to greatness by positive anticipation. That which you call hope. But when that was eventually destroyed painfully, another scar was created. Made me realize that hope is a two-edged sword. One shouldn't rely on it, yet that is inherent to the idea of hope.
Thus, we have people who eventually do public lectures and motivation speeches, telling people the story of how hope pulled them through. What we don't see is speeches about hope making things worse. Because it's too inconvenient to be of sufficient public interest. (Related to the reaon why you never hear positive LSD stories on the news, as Bill Hicks once remarked.)
Hope is literally a popular, traditional confidence trick.

I think, personally, that depression feeds itself. The hormones that our brains produce while depressed can be an addiction. If one were to wake up each morning and tell themselves how lucky they were that they got a chance to exist, irregardless the bad circumstances that they might need to face down today, and would tell themselves the same thing before they go to sleep at night, I think that the depression hormones would subside. The sad part about that is if God does exist and were all waiting to be reborn in some eternal carnival of happiness and joy, it perverts everything. All your pain and suffering is a big cosmic joke. Cause it's all gonna be fixed after you die.

Thanks for allowing millions of children to be born into this world just to die before they even know anything about it. We really needed that. And it really shows you care!

On the flip side, accept that life is random and chaotic and the fact that children suffer and die is because of unfortunate climatic events, political nonsense, and negligence.

There's much more beauty in accepting that and doing the work of saving people from an uncaring universe where we have to work together to survive. It is much more perverse to think we are the pawns of a superman who is responsible for everything, let alone that you must thank him for the privilege of being allowed to be born and die before learning what it means to even be alive.

text:
I got onto this Earth when the sperm cell from my father inseminated the egg inside my mothers fallopian tubes, the egg then travelled to the womb and attached to her womb wall, my cells then multiplied over 9 months until I was a fully formed human no longer dependent on nutrients from my mother so I was born.

Oh no, all that biological science must be a wrong, a magic bearded man in the sky put me here.

If God was real and was really All-Powerful and really loved us all, he would have created a world where everyone gets along, a world were volcanoes don't erupt, hurricanes don't form and tsunami's don't happen, he would have created a world where everyone was happy, where no one was hungry, where everyone found love.

But he didn't, he's created a world that is ruled by corruption and has been for thousands of years, he created a world billions of us are starving, where millions of us sleep on the streets every night, where children contract horrible diseases that give them the most painful death ever, there are children who are born without the ability to see, hear, talk and walk, what sort of a fucking life is that for someone? God.
Isn't.
Real.
