text:
@*****¬†Why does a duck have an 8 inch penis? Why does an elephant weigh 15,000 lbs? Why do platypus lay eggs? Why do bees make honey? Why do birds fly?¬†

The incidence of humans having "rational" brains is no more coincidental than any other anatomical or functional phenomenon in nature. From the least impressive (by human standards) body plan of a sea cucumber, to the most remarkable (by human standards) plumage of birds, every extant organism has one thing in common: it exists. There is no need to delve beyond the provisions of biology as a science in explaining the "coincidences" you so unfortunately perceive.¬†Please do not infer inexplicable mythos from nature for it serves no purpose. And if you were attempting deductive reasoning with the brain you call rational, you should be able to deduce that any form of metaphysical, colloquially referenced "higher being" either: probably doesn't exist; doesn't matter; or is irreconcilable with nature by the perfect, rational brains with which you are assuming we are so gratefully endowed. ¬†

author: Sherman Klump

text: @*****¬†Fair enough. But you didn't answer the question of why a god would make us hungry. And biology and spirituality confound each other because your religion causes you to believe that there is a god that defies all the laws of physics, can create universes with its own volition, and prescribes ethics to his "children", while us humans along with all other tangible life forms are bound by physical and chemical laws, must consume matter to make energy (if we don't we will die), and mate with others to reproduce (if we don't we will die). Just saying god is the father of everything is 100% dependent on faith and counts as shamelessly sitting on the fence because you want to sound intelligent and spiritual at the same time. Biology and spirituality are mutually exclusive, there is no reason to believe in god other than the fact that you were convinced there is one (probably at a young age), and almost every biological question has already been, or is soon to be explained by us mere humans. Maybe you just need to understand the science better and then you will realize how unnecessary the idea of a god is. There's no such thing as heaven or hell so stop worrying about how good you appear to your invisible friend who is completely unapparent and does not give a shit about you.¬†

text:
You know, I wasn't made perfect either. I have a brain, with which I still forget things, perhaps more than other brains do. I have legs, with which I can only run so far, perhaps less than other legs do. I have hands with which I can only use to the best of my own ability, perhaps a little less than other have. But I still look past these and do what I can. I'm still a human being with my own passions, and so is the young man with Progeria. You're assuming another human being is lower than you by saying a loving God wouldn't let this happen. But have you considered that a loving God wouldn't make us inequal? He wouldn't give any tribulation to us save we can actually get through it, and He gives it to us to prove that we are stronger than our bodies. He actually loves us and supports us.
Consider the fact that we are all human beings with bodies that could only take us so far. However we all have spirits that can carry us beyond our own capacity. This young man with Progeria has a spirit much stronger than his body, so the fact that he has Progeria is irrelevant. We can learn a thing or two from this guy.
I say that it is a loving Heavenly Father who encourages us, cheering us on from the heavens, to look past the limits we have and become the person He wants each one of us to be, based on our own qualities which make us unique; he can make a better "you" than you think. Besides, who are you to say that He doesn't show His love to the world? Such a statement is exceedingly ungrateful, and you should know that He does a lot more for your good than anyone else does.
I would hope that the Spirit may enlighten you one day to come to know the love which our God in Heaven has for you and I.

author: Joseph Gardam

text: @Joseph Gardam¬†Sorry, I'm not following you here. Are you saying it's wrong to afford disabled people special treatment? Or that it's ok to say hateful things out of spite? I'm really not getting what your point is supposed to be. It would be different if someone with such a debilitating disability came here and started spewing hateful garbage while people defended them just because they're disabled. But that's not what happened. This is a video of someone with a terrible medical condition just trying to make the best of their life and inspire others. Then some people decided to make hateful comments about him for some reason (trolling, or self hate, or whatever reason; I really don't know why) It's not even close to the same thing. You're right in saying that people shouldn't be hateful towarde others, even when those same people are hateful (that just spreads misery and intolerance), but trying to morally defend someone who's spewing the written equivalent of raw sewage under the guise of "equality" is just illogical.

text:
I'll explain to you what it's like, as best I can at least.
Every day, I have to fight off this urge. Every day I have to survive my mind because every night, when it gets quiet I'm visited by this emotion. This feeling, and it only lasts for a very brief moment.
I can't explain exactly what it feels like, what the experience is, but it's bad. It's dark, dry and void. It's a feeling of dark metaphysical closure, an answer. An unrelenting anthropocosmic understanding of my collected human experience.¬†
Imagine a void like a colorless grey box filled with static that's surrounding you flowing through your meridian, rapidly taring apart your existence and separating you from reality. That's the best I can describe it, and trust me, it still doesn't do it justice. Not even slightly.
It's almost like being crushed down and stuffed inside a tiny box, and every day a veil grows between you and everyone else. Like there's something separating you from the rest of the world. Every day, this veil grows thicker and every day I become more and more disconnected. I thought moving to first shift would help this somehow. I was wrong.
And it's getting worse, it's happening more often, and eventually I'm going to be fucked. I've caused this, and I know this but I've been dealing with it as best I can, but now my best isn't enough and eventually I'm going to lose and when I do I'm dead. That much I do know.
I'm going to be dead and nobody will ever have even truly known me. I think I've somehow acknowledged this as a fact and once I eventually learn to accept it, that's when It'll be game over. And never in my life has this feeling been so welcoming, so fucking alluring. I'm starting to actually want it. The good days are what keep me going. And every day is a good day, but even my best days are getting darker and I've had more than my fair share of darkness, both literally and mentally.
I just hope I don't run out of music. What the fuck is wrong with me.
The worst part about this whole situation is, the happier I become, the more devastating the apposing emotion is. I become so happy some days that I guess I'm just destined to fall into depression, and the happier I become, the more devastating the outcome. If that makes any sense. I have to remain in a perpetual state of melancholy, because if I don't, I break down. I can't experience happiness because if I do, my mind will break down and I'll snap. The happier I become, the closer I get to that breaking point
This isn't a fucking game. It's serious, and it's very, very punishing and unrelenting. It's literally like fighting for your fucking life.
author: „ÅäÂåñ„Åë

text:
First of all I want to say that I don't intend to insult anyone, I respect Sam Berns and I wish He could rest in peace; I'm just trying to have an inteligent conversation on the internet!
Why would He be "much more inside than most of the fucks partying, swagging and bitching around"? What did He do for the human kind? What did He do apart from talking about his own life/disease? I tell You what ... nothing.
"Not everyone can be as brave as he is" Again, what did He do to achieve that ¬†compliment? He spoke in front of an audience, that surely isn't easy and most of people (including me) wouldn't do It but He didn't do anything special, really. What makes him special, very sadly, is having that disease. You are idolizing him just because He has a disease, just because You feel sorry for him. I hate jackasses but I also hate dumb moralism.
Anyway I do not justify all those people that writed those really mean comments, as personally I think that people who are that indifferent to their own equals should not be classified as human beings, I just wanted to say how I think about It.

author: Edward Owens

text: @Edward Owens Oh no this entity is not more powerfull than God you can rest assured. However this planet is his kingdom for the time being. God can stop this entity at any time, in fact God could have stopped Satan before he was even created him since he knew this would happen. That then begs the question why didn't he? Now I want you to stop for a second and read very carefully and think about what you are about to read since the answer to this question is not simple, if it were people wouldn't be asking. ESSAY INCOMING: Imagine a world where there is no sin, where there is no evil where there is no suffering. Now you might say that's what the universe was like before Satan turned evil. You would be wrong though. A true and loving God like ours would never create such a world. Why? Because that world is a fake a world like that can never exist. A word where the only answer to what is your name is your acual name is a lie itself since we have no choice. We have no choice to say the truth or not to say the truth. God gives a choice. A choice to chose not to follow his will. He doesn't want to have a bunch of robots following his orders blindly. Satan was the first to question God's authority. Being second in charge he wanted more. He asked himself why can't I be god? His greed led to his downfall. When Satan and 1/3 of the angels rebelled against God, he could have destroyed them all on the spot. But again that would only prove to be a fake God trying to create a fake world. A world without a choice - a lie. If God had killed Satan then all of the other angels would immediately question his authority. Why kill Satan? He was so holy, number 2 in charge. What did he ever do wrong? Keep in mind they didn't even know what sin was at the time. If God didn't let Satan do as he please he would have created a world of fear where people obeyed him only due to beign scared of being destroyed. It is important to keep in mind that after God created his most favorite world of all (ours) the Devil went to all of the other creatures in the heavens tempting them but the ones on our planet were the ONLY ones that fell into this temptation and this sinned as well. Every single human born today also sins at one point or another in their lives. That is why there is death in this world is because of sin not because God likes death. God can't be there 24/7 and hold our hand and elimite every single bad thing that happens in our lives. That will also be a lie if nothing bad ever happens to anyone. It would be the same as destoying Satan the second he rebelled. Do not worry though all of this will be over very soon. Many prophesies have already been fulfilled and the time will come when God will not tollerate all of this suffering any longer. And at that time every single being in the universe will know that he is right and just. There will be no more suffering and death. The reason I am explain all of this is it makes me sad to hear people blame God for everything bad that happens in their lives when in reality he does so much good for us.

author: NimeniOwens

text:
@NimeniOwens¬†You said "Firstly, neither atheists nor believers cannot proof their arguments."

Sir, I don't have anything to prove. ¬†*YOU* DO.

I have no more responsibility to disprove YOUR god than any of the other thousands...or leprechauns or the Tooth Fairy. ¬†If I have to disprove the thousands of other gods then SO DO YOU!!!!!

HOW did you do it?!?!?!

Extraordinary claims REQUIRE extraordinary evidence so your suggestion that your particular god actually exists (out of thousands of others which we BOTH agree are fictional) REQUIRES extraordinary proof...not an ancient book from ignorant goat herders. ¬†As I stated previously, there is ZERO reason to separate your particular god from the remaining thousands. ¬†Allah didn't create mankind with a magic wave of his hand and Muhammad didn't fly up to the clouds on a "magical winged animal". ¬†They all appear to be fairy tales from ignorant ancient people.

The Quran is a conglomeration of equine excrement...just like so many other books about gods.

"That's it. Good luck."
author: CynicalSkeptic1

text:
@NimeniOwens¬†I think you and Mr. Carl Jung have both confused necessity and desire. This DESIRE hails from humanity's natural inclination to thirst for knowledge and understanding. Thusly, in the primordial ages of history, humanity sought to develop a belief system that was apt for the philosophical questions around them (such as those of origin, after death occurrences, etc.). And as Christopher Hitchens says, "Religion comes from the period of human prehistory where nobody...had the smallest idea what was going on. It comes from the bawling and fearful infancy of our species, and is a babyish attempt to meet our inescapable demand for knowledge (as well as for comfort, reassurance and other infantile needs)."¬†

These fatuous dogmas were manufactured as specious, illusory fabrications to provide alleviation and a spurious sense of resolution through feigned understanding. ¬†
author: Jeremy Jones

text:
@CynicalSkeptic1¬†Dude, why does it look like everything you say here is always bordering on being at the top of your lungs? That's kinda tripping me out.

Also, sorry to say it, but you're wrong. At least in some fashion, that is. @NimeniOwens¬†Absolutely does not need to prove the existence of his God, nor does he have to disprove the existence of the thousands of others. It's really hard for some people to understand this, but having a believe system doesn't require proof. Gasp Whaatt?¬†

Yeah, it's true. Believing in some sort of deity is inherently different from knowing that there is, lets say, gravity. Why? Well, because the existence and effect of gravity is a factual one, with evidence and studies and experiments on in from early science with Newton all the way up until now where it is definitely regarded as a huge, meta-physical fact. Gravity is something that no one questions, and if no one questions it then no one has to believe it. They know it.¬†

Most usually, when someone believes in one God, they do not believe in any others (obviously.) In this way they are like you in that you would both collectively agree on believing in the Non-existence of 99.9% of proposed deities out there. But that's it. Believe systems are found everywhere, even in you, good sir. To that point, if I were to ask you what gravity is, and how it was caused, you could scour the Earth for the smartest people and end up with no definitive answer because no one has found that out yet. But I'm sure that you believe that it has something to do with astrophysics and some other sort of mega-science that I probably don't understand. Well, there it is, you believe in something that you can't prove. Welcome abord, laddy!

Listen man, all I'm trying to say, is that you can't tell someone to prove the existence of something they believe in. It sounds incredibly dumb to you, I know, trust me. But you simply can't do it. It's like defining gravity.

P.S. Please, in future debates, do not refer to a God or gods as fairytales, magic people in the sky, or relate them to Santa Claus or the Easter Bunny. It is childish and makes you you very ignorant, weakening your argument considerably. "Oh, it makes ME look ignorant?!? What about them for their beliefs?!" You might be saying to yourself. Well if they look that dumb to you, and they think that the Easterbunny statement is an ignorant one, then try to imagine just how ignorant you appear to them in that moment. Yeah I know, it's a lot.
author: theneilplumley

text:
@theneilplumley¬†You said "Dude, why does it look like everything you say here is always bordering on being at the top of your lungs?"

If you mean that I have information "at the ready" it is because I have debated hundreds and hundreds of religious believers and have an enormous amount of contradictory evidence for gods. I was a Christian myself for 20 years and reading my Bible from cover to cover is what originally made me an atheist.

You also said "NimeniOwens¬†Absolutely does not need to prove the existence of his God, nor does he have to disprove the existence of the thousands of others."

Sir, if you have ZERO evidence to support your beliefs...then there is ZERO reason to believe them. Okay? Nimeni states that he believes in one of thousands of gods...yet has no reason for this belief. He may as well believe in leprechauns and the Easter Bunny.

You said "In this way they are like you in that you would both collectively agree on believing in the Non-existence of 99.9% of proposed deities out there."

Then OBVIOUSLY there is no reason to separate one particular god from the remainder. If ALL of the other thousands¬†appear FICTIONAL and there is ZERO evidence for his particular deity...then there is also ZERO reason for his belief. ¬†Sure, he can believe whatever he likes...but since he doesn't require evidence for his beliefs then they are worthless.

You also said "Please, in future debates, do not refer to a God or gods as fairytales, magic people in the sky, or relate them to Santa Claus or the Easter Bunny. It is childish and makes you you very ignorant, weakening your argument considerably."

Sir, I couldn't care less how YOU believe it makes me appear...gods seem to be fictional...just like Santa Claus and the Tooth Fairy...they ALL appear to be in the same category...FICTIONAL.

author: CynicalSkeptic1

text:
@CynicalSkeptic1¬†Hey man, you totally didn't understand what I was trying to say. What I was trying to get across is that if you want to successfully debate the topic of "Hey, is there some sort of God out there or not?" then you're going about it the wrong way.

Here's why: There is no evidence for God.

There is no evidence for Allah.

There is no concrete, remarkable proof for the existence of any higher power.

We know this. We ALL know this. There are people who believe in God or Allah or Shiva or Anubis or Odin who know this. If you walk into a Christian Church and ask for evidence of an existing god, and urged them to understand that you meant you wanted actual concrete, indisputable evidence, they would say that they don't have any, but that they believe because the Bible tells them so, or because they feel God's presence, or any of the dozens of other reasons.

We know there is no evidence of God, and yet regardless of this universal knowledge, pointing out this lack of physical evidence seems to be your entire argument. You may think that it's a strong one, because how can someone believe in something that hasn't been proven? Well, they can do that because believing in something transcends facts, it transcends reason. Believing, by definition, is without proof. So you saying that one can't or shouldn't believe in something because there are no facts to back it up is total bologna because that is actually the only way for someone to believe in something. If there were facts to back up someones beliefs, they wouldn't have to believe it because at that point it would be knowledge. And knowledge is known, not believed in. ¬†

Does that make sense?

Your argument contradicts itself. You demand facts from people who have none, because they believe in the existence of something that they cannot prove to anyone.¬†

You might as well just ask for facts about who is going to win the Superbowl in 2016. Guess what? You can't. Those facts don't exist. But I'll bet you all the cash in my underwear drawer that die hard sports fans across the country will tell you that their team will win the Superbowl. How could they know this?!?! Are they psychic?!? No. They're not. They don't know it because that knowledge does not exist. They believe it. Now I know this isn't the same thing as believing in a deity, but hopefully it paints a proper picture.

So by this logic, @NimeniOwens¬†(as I stated before) absolutely does not need to prove the existence of his God because if he did, it wouldn't be a belief system, it would be a set of facts. Now, I realize that you most likely live your life in pursuit of facts and proven knowledge, that is awesome and admirable. But that also means that this way of thinking probably doesn't make sense to you, and that it all just seems ridiculous that billions of people will live their life thinking that something is true when it can't be proven. But that's okay, we don't have to know why people do that, we only need to figure out everything else in the history of the universe.

One more reason why you should rework your debate platform is that it includes you reducing entire belief systems into childish things, like Santa and the Easter Bunny. Listen man, it's no skin off my nose how you speak of these things, but when you refer to believing in a God as like expecting Santa to come down the chimney it definitely does make you look childish and uneducated. When people are in an argument they are prone to demeaning or making fun of their rivals platform in order to win it. But when people debate, both sides are respectful and educated in their debate points, and don't resort to childish tactics like name calling, slander and of course, Easter-Bunnificaiton.

Also, no I was not referring to you having information "at the ready" when I said it seemed that everything you said was boarder line at the top of your lungs. I was trying to say that with all the CAPS and BOLDED LETTERS it actually seems that you're yelling all of this at everyone. Just fyi.

P.S. Have you read the Ontological Argument? That's a personal favorite of mine because of it's simplicity.
author: theneilplumley

text: The burden of proof argument is only for ego purposes. It's a red herring because it's made up. Burden of proof only exists in debates. Atheist NEED believers to debate. It keeps them alive as they feel they have a purpose. What you DO is what you believe. You @CynicalSkeptic1¬†have a religion, and it's called God Hate. That's fine, but you do realize you're just wasting your time, and ultimately the irony falls on the atheists every time. At the end of the day: You will die. This logic begs the question: Why are you wasting your ONLY existence arguing with people over whether there is an afterlife or not????
author: Danny 90

text:
@theneilplumley¬†I'm guessing the caps and bold letters are to try and emphasize the main idea that he's been arguing for a long time since sidetracking and overlooking is so common in this type of debagle (it's like a debate, but you can put cream cheese on it!). ¬† Probably didn't start that way, but when you're devoted to an argument that the other side will never properly acknowledge, the rage of that frustration certainly shows over time.

I'm just as frustrated knowing the number of people who exist that I would never be able to get through to about something I see as completely outrageous as religion, but that anger died a long while ago for me. ¬†

Not everyone is the same, and it appears countless people crave something otherworldly to believe in. ¬†I'm not one of those types of people so I cannot understand that need, but I do recognize the differences between me and them in that respect. ¬†

For example, in the very same way that others who are straight don't understand my homosexuality directly, they can recognize that my brain operates differently than theirs, and this is why it's something that 'wouldn't compute' for them.

So while religion doesn't 'compute' for me and instead appears as something completely insane, I know these people aren't insane at all, it's just that I cannot understand their need for a belief. ¬†(and before it's brought up, I'm generalizing, naturally there are insane people in the world, religious or not).

We may also be surprised by how often people don't look at their beliefs so literally. ¬†Many actually end up focusing on the lessons and guidance of their religion while way back in their mind it's being guided by something supernatural and comforting. ¬†

Yeah I know of all the bad associated with religion and all the good. ¬†Personally when I'm looking at the overall picture of humanity, I see religion having done way more harm than good. ¬†But by the same token, it will ALWAYS have been there because craving belief effects a large portion of humanity and will manifest one way or another. ¬†The bad associated with it is the result of bad people in the end, whether they attributed something horrible to the Bible way in the past, or they're shouting 'god hates gays' on the sidewalk.¬†

If for example some insane murderer goes on a rampage killing in the name of god, I don't fault the religion in the same way I don't fault a violent video game for being the cause of a kid shooting up his school. These people are insane to begin with and would have done something outrageous anyway, and if not in the name of religion, in the name of something else.

I know there's a lot of fucked up stories in the Bible for example that applied to the context of the fucked up past, but who in the current day really looks at these stories literally besides the mentally unsound?

In the end the operations of our individual minds can lead us to be/believe/want/do literally anything. ¬†It's important to truly recognize just how differently our biological minds may vary. ¬†

So long as the differences between me and someone religious isn't having a negative effect on my life, I have no problem with it and I don't look down on them.
author: naeseion

text:
@theneilplumley¬†You said "There is no concrete, remarkable proof for the existence of any higher power. ¬†We know this. We ALL know this."

NO "WE" DON'T!!! ¬†As I previously stated, I have debated hundreds and hundreds of religious believers (unlike YOU) and they frequently INSIST that they have evidence for their god and this results in espousing effluvium. So, OBVIOUSLY we DON'T "all know this".

You said "Believing, by definition, is without proof."

As I stated previously, I couldn't care less about your suggestions for modifying my debates. ¬†As I stated previously, there is ZERO evidence for gods just like Santa and the Tooth Fairy. text:
@dfjr1990¬†You said "Atheist NEED believers to debate. It keeps them alive as they feel they have a purpose."

I debate religious believers because religion intrudes upon numerous facets of society...it is on my money and in my pledge of allegiance, and religious fundamentalists attempt to teach ancient superstitious myth in public schools.

Catholic missionaries also teach South Africans to refrain from using condoms which results in millions of additional deaths from AIDS cases.
Religion kills adulterers & homosexuals & "witches", genital mutilation, suicide bombings, etc., etc...

Religion does all these things...you just ignore them.

Christians in Nigeria are murdering their children because the biblical god said "Thou shalt not suffer witches to live." and some of them believe their children are witches. Deja-vu...

Christians in Uganda wanted to execute (it's actually MURDER) homosexuals just like many of the Muslim countries do currently (and adulterers too). They finally capitulated and decided to be more merciful than the Muslims. Homosexuals only get LIFE imprisonment in Uganda.

As I stated previously, religion intrudes upon numerous facets of society but apparently you couldn't care less.

You said "You +CynicalSkeptic1 have a religion, and it's called God Hate."

ROFL!!! Your god doesn't appear to exist...just like the thousands of other gods. ¬†I don't hate your god any more than I hate Thor or Poseidon. ¬†I was a Christian for 20 years and my parents sent me to Christian schools since kindergarten. I began to doubt my faith as I grew older and I turned to my Bible for answers. Becoming more familiar with biblical content resulted in my apostasy. Subsequent conversations with my parents made them question their faith so much that they stopped attending church. All it takes is to apply LOGIC to religion. It fails miserably when subjected to critical scrutiny.
author: CynicalSkeptic1

text:
@CynicalSkeptic1 Sometimes people can have an "open-minded" viewpoint and still be very stubborn in their way of thinking. I think you prove that, Mr. Skeptic. 

Listen, I have not been trying to prove you wrong in what you believe, but try to tell you that by any logical standards, and certainly by the good standards of any season, level-headed debater, your argument itself is flawed. You may not have seen that over your seemingly blind hatred for anything pro-higher power, but I have actually been trying to help you realize that your argument needs work. (please note that while I know you've had much experience commenting on hundreds of other YouTube videos about the strikingly obvious fact that there is no God, I chose to use the exact words "level-headed" to separate you from my generalization of the "seasoned debater." In short, I do not mean you.) 

You are one whom, at this point in your life, seem to be unable to have an open-minded view on this religious debate platform that you hold so dearly (And by "open-minded " I actually mean open-minded in all regards, not just "non-Christian"). This being  so, I choose to not debate this point further with you, because I feel as if it isn't going anywhere. 

Let me be perfectly clear, however. I have not been trying to make you believe in a higher power at all. I'm not trying to debunk the science in which you hold your beliefs. I am not attacking you or trying to say that your world view is wrong. I have been trying to show you that your argument is flawed and if you want to keep fighting this good fight, then you should change gears a bit here. You might make a shark of a lawyer, a good one too, but you'll never be a Descartes or Aquinas. 

You are trying to prove, through logic and reason, that your beliefs are true, and those two were some of the best in history at doing that. My question about the Ontological was actually a test, and your response means that you failed. The Ontological is regarded as being the height of logical reason for people at that time. It is a landmark in philosophy history. Every great debater of life and origin can cite and respect it's significance, and using the word "pathetic" to describe it, it seems that you do not. 

I will no longer have this debate with you, because asking you to think differently, in this stage of your life, is like asking gravity to let me go from this Earth. It's just not going to happen. 

I wish you well, and hope you have a good week.
author: N Plumley

text:
@B. Neil Plumley¬†You said "Sometimes people can have an "open-minded" viewpoint and still be very stubborn in their way of thinking. I think you prove that, Mr. Skeptic."

Sir, I was a Christian for 20 years and actually investigating my religion including reading my Bible from cover to cover is what made me an atheist. ¬†Since that time I have discovered an ENORMOUS amount of evidence which contradicts my previously-held beliefs...including researching numerous other religions. ¬†So, if you want to call me a "stubborn atheist" I truly couldn't care less. ¬†My beliefs are based on thorough investigation. ¬†I AM open-minded or I wouldn't have changed my religious beliefs. ¬†I am STILL open-minded if someone actually had valid proof for a god. ¬†My experience after debating hundreds and hundreds of religious believers is that there is ZERO valid evidence for any gods. ¬†Again, this is based on thorough research and debating hundreds of believers.

As I stated previously, I sincerely couldn't care less if you don't appreciate my debate style. ¬†I also sincerely couldn't care less if I "failed your test". ¬†I will continue attempting to curtail ignorance and you can continue calling informed atheists stubborn.

I hope you also have a very happy 4th and good luck to you.
author: CynicalSkeptic1

text:
@Ryan Hutton Who are you to determine what someone can say or how they choose to express themselves. Personally I hate it when disgruntled people spend too much time living vicariously through the internet and picking fights because they don't have the balls to say what they want to people in real life. Although I'm sure I'm just making an assumption you'll tell me.


P.S I'm also an Atheist.
author: BillCutting1855

text:
@BillCutting1855¬†What? Where did that come from? Picking fights on the internet because abc? Well, I'll have you know talking to people on the internet is a far more efficient way of changing minds than walking about preaching, it has nothing to do with "balls". I guess you think female preachers aren't real or something.

Anyway, who am I to determine what people say? That's a non-sequiter. I'm merely mediating what people ought to say and it's not me who is the origin of that ought, if it was then there wouldn't really be any imperative to act in any particular way, rather it is logic that is the origin of that ought. People are free to be stupid if they want, but there is a moral imperative to not be in my opinion and I'm telling them how to fulfill that moral imperative.¬†
author: Senpai Torpid DOW

text:
@Ryan Hutton
For someone who "seems" so smart surely you can see I thought my own comment was ironic. It's not exactly hard to miss. You knew full well I said "balls" in a figurative manner too.

You're not mediating either because you're clearly imposing what YOU deem to be correct and saying others that think differently are stupid. That's an agenda. I've already stated that I'm an Atheist. I just wanted to express my empathy for this young man and I thought this was a fitting way of doing so without offending anyone. But you can always rely on the elitist arseholes of Youtube to correct someone on what "should" be a correct and worthy response.

That arsehole is you Ryan.

text: This is an extremely narrow minded and uneducated comment that perpetuates ignorance. First on the subject of money. If you would like to purpose a logistical alternative socioeconomic system that can allocate scare resources, turn subjective value into objective (by weighting mass subjective demand into monetary market objective value), and enlighten me on how money "itself" is the problem then I would happily shut up. But it's obvious that when people say general statements like this they are uneducated about the subject matter. Money is NOT the problem. Money is simply a way to represent subjective value for goods and services in the market place. Now as for the second half of your comment: Argumentum Ad Ignorantiam, Confirmaiton Bias, and¬†Cum Hoc Ergo Propter Hoc.¬†
author: Edward R.
Emily Johnson

text: @Edward M. Rippen¬†Before you throw statements about my ignorance around I was refering to humanities relationship with money. We idolise money in a very unhealthy way and put it before real values and it's clouding our morality. Very foolish of you to attempt to undermine me with your comments and to be quite fair I don't understand a lot of what you wrote because I'm not educated in finance. You clearly have a large ego and get some kind of buzz from trying to portray how intelligent you are.¬†
author: The Pale Man

text: @James Omahony¬†my apologies, I should have wrote in a less objective manner, I didn't mean to come off as condescending or rude. @Emily Johnson¬†in regards to your comments, I would just like to add the following. It is up to society to decide on what values are important (or not important). What money does is enable us ¬†to do exactly so. Many people value material goods because of the significance our society puts on them. But saying "material goods" is just as misleading. Truly anything and everything is a "material good". Maybe these "material goods" have become less practical and more stylish but nonetheless there is meaning and voting happening behind the scenes by both you and the rest of consumers in our economy. One could make the argument however, that these "stylish materials" are just as powerful in regards to being a piece of art than the art that is so readily defended by you and others. But the reason why money is so powerful is because it doesn't lie. If a "good" or "service" is not producing value for other human beings, (if a material object has no significance or purpose to people) the ability to sustain production of that good/service is dependent on purchases. This simple idea means that people that are performing services such as these art(s) you cited can get real feedback on the how valuable it is to others. And if it's not producing value, than the resources wasted can't be justified. Going back to the point that we have "scarcity" not abundance of resources. And I'd like to elaborate even further on this. When you say "gives meaning" you must realize that there is "meaning" behind material, even if it is simply embellishment of oneself. We communicate sensually, and part of those senses is sight. So conveying a message no doubt even through material creates an emotional experience which can translate to meaning when interpreted through a different perspective. Lastly @James Omahony¬† I am not attacking you, I am attacking the statement you made that money is the problem. Money is merely a means to an end, but an efficient one when concerning subjective values in an economy. To acquire money you must provide value to society. It forces us to be productive beings knowing we can attain it and use it to acquire those goods and services that we individually value. And if people value TEDx, people will request more of it, people will pay for it, and people will even demand it. This notion can be applied to almost all services and products in an efficient economic system.¬†
author: Edward R.

text: No problem, I accept your apology and you have some good points as regard your views
author: The Pale Man

text:
@Edward M. Rippen¬†So I had about 20 lines written up, was only about halfway done, and then YouTube pooped out on me.. I will attempt to recreate it.

I started off explaining how I only commented in the first place because of how rude you were to James Omahony, and then thanked you for apologizing to him.¬†

We live in a society where the motto seems to be that "more is never enough". We may buy that Mercedes we have been dreaming of for 3+ year, but 1 month after we get it we become disappointed and develop new dreams of getting the next model newer. We never fully appreciate the success of reaching our goals, because once we reach them we always want more, or better, or newer.¬†

I think it is very important that more people develop a mindset of appreciating what they do have. They might not have the nicest house on their street, but it is their house, it has running water, electricity, and enough space for them and their family. Sure, the countertops need replacing, the floors need to be refinished, and that box TV needs to be upgraded, but enjoy the nuances, find beauty in the rough floors, admire the strangeness of the out of date countertops‚Ä¶ it won't last forever.¬†

"Many people value material goods because of the significance our society puts on them".¬†
Exactly. But I do not agree with your statement: "truly everything and anything is a material good".¬†
A material good is one that is just that, materialistic.. tangible in nature.¬†

Imagine for a moment that you are standing in a tropical forest where no humans have made their mark, no talking, no cars, no pollution, just the wind, the birds, and the creaking of the trees. Does this not have value? It most defiantly is not a material good. But most would say this type of beauty has value.¬†

I saw a funny cartoon the other day‚Ä¶ It was actually a Retweet from Boogie, which read: "Yes, the planet got destroyed. But for a beautiful moment in time we created a lot of value for shareholders."¬†
The US has a greater GDP than Bhutan‚Ä¶ but Bhutan doesn't focus on production and profits‚Ä¶ they focus on GNH: Gross National Happiness. The US has a higher rate of depression than Bhutan, but we're richer so that must mean we're better! Right?

I think most people would place a bigger priority on happiness than goods or services they consume. If a I had a choice between being the parent of a poor family with 5 kids living in a 2 bedroom apartment with a positive outlook on life and experiencing pure happiness‚Ä¶ or being the parent of a excessively rich family with 2 perfect straight A students living in a mansion in Beverly Hills who is consistently severely depressed‚Ä¶ I would choose the former.¬†

This scenario is probably more likely than most people think. We live in a society that tells us: "the more you have, the happier you'll be". But as everyone who is anyone has experienced in their life, that new toy you really wanted for Christmas, or that new car you were dreaming of for 3+ years, it didn't make you any happier in the long run. It just increased the level of your goals in the future.¬†

text:
Due to a motocross injury I lived in a wheel chair for about 4 moths, you speak the truth when you wrote how differently people treated you. Its amazing how socially 'unacceptable' it is to be 'disabled' and the amount of irreverence people have for those who are different from them is remarkable.¬†

After going through something, like you that was only moderately debilitating it can give you a new outlook on life. But this will only happen if you let it. 2 years later I wake up each morning and praise the lord I can stand up out of bed instead of crawl to the bathroom and hoist myself onto the toilet. Just as you are glad to have the use of your entire hand back I am sure...

You are correct, people are dicks, there are far too many of them and as such they will drag others down with them. As you said, we all must remember to rise above the dicks and stop being rude to people. Sound advice given by funkster505!¬†

Thank you for the video and wonderful tips on how to lead a happier life! Good luck in your bio / chemistry education.¬†

author: Alex Watson

text: We cannot deny the fact that he is only happy as a corollary of people suffering. If people did not suffer at the idea of not keeping him alive, he would not have the ability to be alive or happy. His philosophy may be how he reasons his happiness, and there is truth to that, but there is also truth in his illness being the main cause of his happiness. Therefore, it is contradictory to exalt happiness if the happiness only exists because of suffering. They would logically both have equal value, and thus it makes just as much sense telling people how to be happy as it does how to suffer. What we are really trying to exalt here is the intent of the will to do good. It is not enough to be happy, sometimes we must have pain in order to sharpen and focus our will to do good. Just as he transmuted his suffering to do good in his life. That is the real inspiration here.¬†

author: Sharon Ojala

text:
What Bryan Lee¬†is saying, from my understanding-- is that Sam isn't happy for the simple reason of being happy. He is happy because he has nothing else to be. There is no distraction in his life. No expectations, there isn't much he can change. The common complications we experience aren't a¬†concern to him. He's most likely come to terms with his impairment and accepts them and has no delusions or long term desires to fall short of.

We're unhappy, why? Money.. not feeling desired.. being hurt or cheated on by people we care about? While a part of him may long to be an average person, there is a psychological burden that comes with it. So, I think, Bryan is expressing that what makes him sad is that Sam's happiness is a result of being impaired. It's a lose-lose, really. Sam is happy because we see him as an¬†inspiration due to his impairment. Sam is happy because there is no concern for money, sex, the future, aging. He's happy because he has nothing else to be.

Just my interpretation of the comment. I found it¬†to be an interesting perspective. And while I appreciate Sam and all he stands for, I don't disagree with the ideas expressed here. If we're being¬†real.¬†
author: Sean P

text: I think Bryan's comment¬† is right on and I get what he is saying. What I got from Sam's 12 minute video was simple is all I was saying. We all have a choice how we deal with the cards dealt to us. Of course Sam would not have the same outlook if he had different parents, was not sick and was poor. He was molded into this incredible person by the people who raised him and by his circumstances.¬† I'm sure these parents taught him through example that Sam¬† had choices in how he dealt with his circumstance and he was choosing to be happy. Which is not really Happy as in the word most people perceive it to be. I believe he meant happy as in "being at peace" or having "inner joy" and just enjoying his friends and family. That's what I got from the video anyway.. I hope others can view without pity and just soak in his words because the message is really awesome and could be life changing if applied :)
author: Sharon Ojala

text: What I got from the vid is a person doing his best to deal with a very hard reality. Most people have to deal with something hard sooner or later. Maybe it's the death of a loved one, or cruel or unfair treatment from others, or some natural disaster that strikes, or some terrible disease that befalls. When that happens, we can, usually with some help, choose to press on and do our best; or we can choose to do something less -- maybe just give up, or lash out at someone or something, or just roll over and die. Sam chose to press on and be one of the Good Guys. And he set an example for those who, facing a terrible reality, would like to do the same and just need a little guidance and courage. I thank him for that. Sometimes all we need is a little reminder to get through a tough spot and make a good decision that will positively affect the rest of our lives and the lives of those around us.

author: salam algerie

text:
¬†wanted to share a theory I had about life... this is based on opinion only and I hope it provides some happiness in your life. (This is not about god vs atheist please take that debate elsewhere)
To think life's only purpose is death is a rather sad thought, causes depression in those who believe their lives will revert back to what it was like before you were born. It wasn't a very memorable experience before you born was it? Imagine being in that realm of non-existence for all eternity, it makes those think their life is pointless and I'm only here to tell you my thoughts on life and why you should cherish it. I did believe in some form of reincarnation for the longest time, because there is something else to us that gives us life. Without getting into god vs atheist I won't call it a soul but there is something behind life we don't fully understand. If you connected a brain, lungs, heart ect. and pumped blood through it then tried to stimulate the brain into working order nothing would happen. This is where life energy, chi or a soul comes into question. Now according to scientific research energy cannot be destroyed, energy can only transfer or spread (thin-out). There is a natural energy to our body and mind that is believed to be our soul. When we die our body may be gone but that residual energy will... go somewhere (we don't know) maybe that energy contains who you are. However if reincarnation was true what happens when there is no more life on this planet to reincarnate? When this planet dies, becomes destroyed or becomes inhabitable what will happen then?

With that said I can't truly believe in the "nothing" version of afterlife that most of the population believes. That we will revert back to what it was like before we were born, because science shows for every action there is a reaction, cause and effect... and that plays into the idea that there is something beyond this life. Nothing in this universe is pointless, and for mankind to simply revert back to that realm of non-existence again for all eternity would be pointless. Maybe Star Wars was right, maybe there is a force that binds all living things together. We are not independent individuals, we need others to survive when we are born and when we grow we long for companionship, we need each other in this world and we would need each other in the next one. Maybe by simply existing we created something in universe, something or somewhere we go to after we pass away. And what is this force that binds us? How do we grow emotions for each other. What baffles me the must is, how does a planet have every thing it needs in order for life to be here? The O-Zone layer, the perfect distance from the sun so its not too hot or too cold, the molten lava under our crust keeping our planet warm during nighttime, plants that provide our air, a natural system that causes rain to supply these plants with the very thing they need to survive and a protective atmosphere which shields us from gases and meteors/debris. So many things needed for life to grow yet here it is despite all odds stacked against it. Maybe there is something greater out there we don't understand... for our perspective is our greatest illusion, it made us think the planet was flat and that our planet was the center of the universe. Who knows what illusions we continue to see.

It's these things that make me disbelieve the theory that we got back to that realm of non-existence couldn't be true. You cannot go back to the way things were before you born, it's impossible... you can't undo your existence, to revert back to that state is impossible because you are here right now. And our body and minds may be destroyed but our energy would live on for eternity. And as we are drawn to each other in this world energy is no different, we bind to each other like molecules. And maybe those bonds we form here continue on after our bodies are gone. Maybe that energy goes back to the place it came, back to the stars. Maybe this is only a stepping stone into life. Maybe our end here is just the beginning to something greater. Because we can't know for sure that's why it's best to live this life as much as you can. And I mean that, you waited 4.5 billion years to be here... and when you die if there is something else beyond this life the only things you'll be able to take with you is your thoughts, your memories and your personality. Money, cars, houses, jewelry and all that trash will remain here for it is not important. The important things in life are family, friends, loved ones, experiencing new things, learning, growing and exploring. Seek out all you can here, experience as much as you can while you're here. You really want a lifetime of working long hours to be your in-flight movie to your next life? It would be a pretty boring movie.Ôªø
Show less

text:
Agree. Just c couple of things:

1. The lava under the crust of the earth does not keep the planet warm at night. The atmosphere absorbing and retaining the sun's energy does that.

2. The atmosphere does not necessarily keep most of the harmful radiation from the sun out. The lava under the crust of the earth does most of that. :D
author: Mike Morrison

text:
@Mike Morrison It doesn't completely protect us from harmful UV rays, it does however dim it habitable conditions. But what the Ozone layer and atmosphere does is protect us from other harmful gases from space. Which believe it or not, happens quite often. Luckily we don't know what harmful gases come near our planet cause our protective bubble keeps it out, however NASA has been studying this for a while and have some interesting theories on where it comes from but there are still many things we don't know about our own galaxy.

But the lava under the crust of earth does indeed provide us extra heat. The Ozone does a better job at that by trapping in the heat. But a small percentage of that heat comes naturally from our planet. Not an abundance of heat but a noticeable amount. The core of the earth's temperature matches that of the surface temperature on the sun. That heat rises and goes to the top, it gets cooler the further it goes but it does provide a difference in our temperature at night. The majority of the heat goes back down to be heated up once against like boiling a pot of water. If we didn't have that heat under us there would be rather large drop in temperature at night in a lot of places around the world.

author: PurpleStratocaster

text:
@DocHollowDay
1. I never said the atmosphere doesn't HELP in protecting us. I said it doesn't do most of the work.Really, it is only the ozone layer that helps to absorb a relatively small amount of UV rays from the sun. (The ozone layer does not trap heat, btw. It absorbs UV rays. Carbon dioxide, methane and other gases traps heat. And it traps it from the solar radiation, not from lava.) Our core does the vast majority of the work of protecting our planet. We have a molten iron core. It literally creates a magnetic shield that extends far above the atmosphere.

2. The core of the earth most certainly does not warm the atmosphere. The only reason why we have the atmosphere we have today, is not because of the hot lava, but because of the gases released from volcanic eruptions, and from meteor impacts for a couple of billion years.

3. "We don't know what harmful gases come near our planet." Uuuhhh....there is really no "harmful gases" that are coming to the earth. The "harmful stuff" is called "radiation." It's not a gas. And we know what it is. We have known for literally over a century now. And it comes from the sun, and a small amount from the rest of the universe. The reason why the rest of the universe does not contribute more radiation to our solar system, is simply because the sun, like the earth, has a vast magnetic field because of the vast amount of iron in the sun. Only the sun is many, many times larger than the earth, and therefore, it's magnetic field reaches out to the furthest reaches of our solar system. (Not quite, but it's reach is quite far out there.)

4. "We don;t know much about our own galaxy." Except that we know just as much about our galaxy as we do the universe itself. Our galaxy is in the universe, afterall. The great scientific mysteries that we are currently studying, is not about our galaxy, but the universe as a whole. We are studying "dark energy" and "dark matter."

5. "The core of the earth's temperature matches that of the surface temperature on the sun." Yes. It does.

6. "That heat rises and goes to the top, it gets cooler the further it goes but it does provide a difference in our temperature at night. The majority of the heat goes back down to be heated up once against like boiling a pot of water. If we didn't have that heat under us there would be rather large drop in temperature at night in a lot of places around the world."

No. It doesn't. At all. That is not at all how our planet-wide ecosystem works. A small amount of lava escaping around the planet does not heat the planet at night. Most of the lava escaping is on the sea floor, not on land. It doesn't heat the planet. Not even locally. That...just.....no.

text:
@Robert Henrichs¬†Explaining why I have to ¬†disagree is not the same as to hate someone's belief. Hating someone's belief is pointless. Arguing WHY I hold a different belief makes plenty of sense to me. Going by your logic we shouldn't even bother to argue about fictional beings, but that's where you are wrong.

Besides, weren't you the one trying to lecture people on their beliefs and grammar to make a point that's not even really that valid to begin with? The only validity lies in your assumption of God being real. An assumption is no valid reason for us to agree.

I was merely stating the obvious and I am not someone to hold a grudge against anyone. I just think I can have an opinion on your extremely biased world view.¬†

That view where you are the one who insinuates that hating on God or disliking it as being just another fictional character was somehow extremely immature, as if there's any valid reason whatsoever for a fictional God to be different from a cartoon character. Yes, for someone who doesn't believe in God, it is actually the very same thing. Even worse, the very belief in say Santa Claus, the Tooth fairy, Tom&jerry, God and what not are equally immature by their very definition of being (stories about) fictional characters.¬†

It doesn't matter if it's hate, disliking, disapproval or whatever else. From any more neutral point of view it's just another opinion I have to disagree with because logic implies so.

Prove to me that God is not a fictional being belonging in the same category as a cartoon character, Santa Claus and so on and we'd have a different discussion altogether.

For example about what inexplicable logic goes behind blessing people with horrible diseases if that very God is supposed to be 'good', infallible, omnipotent, merciful and so on. You're a slave to that ridiculous assumption.

Your entire world view is based around that single assumption of God being real, when in reality there's not the slightest reason to really ¬†make that assumption from a logical point of view in the first place?

author: thatWUdoothatUdo

text:
Ah Darlur, I feel more bad for you than I do for this young man because of your comments that show something of your attitude about your own life. Cyber hug to you, sir. It would likely do you good to re-listen to this young man a few times and maybe take heart from the message he is sharing about how he deals with his life struggles. Perhaps you could learn something for your own life struggles?

We all have our struggles to varying degrees. Listening to his perspective was helpful for me to realize that I can have a better personal attitude about my own health problems that keep me from doing what I wish sometimes.That I can also do work-arounds and hold an attitude to take advantage of what I can do and focus less on what I can't. Find folks that are uplifting and supportive to be around. Keep "moving forward", as best as you can enjoying life while you can. Good advice from anyone, IMO. His having overcome such difficult life obstacles makes him more worthy of listening to because of knowing that he has "been there". He speaks from truth hard learned.¬†

I am sad to read from someone's comments that this young man has died since this video. Knowing something of the disease, then this is not a complete surprise. Progeria is definitely bad luck in life's lotto and hopefully someday will have answers to mitigate this disease and others that cause so much suffering.¬†

My life's lotto isn't as good as some, but a lot better than many others. It is up to me to make the best of my abilities to have the best life possible. I thank this young man for sharing and will now go try to act on his advice! I recommend you do the same... dear angry Darlur. Peace!
